editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the Theatre Royal.

q.l: Egregiam verò laudem, & polia ampla refertis;
Una, dolo, Divûm, i Foemina victa duorum et.

div.p: To which is added, The MUSICK of the SONGS. Compos'd by Mr. Henry Purcel.
LONDON, Printed for J. Tonon, at the Judges Head in Chancery-lane near Fleet-treet; and M. Tonon at Gray's-Inn-Gate in Gray's-Inn-Lane. 1691.

div.head: To the Honourable Sir WILLIAM LEVISON GOWER, Bar.
div.p:
THere is one kind of Vertue, which is inborn in the Nobility, and indeed in mot of the Ancient Families of this Nation; they are not apt to inult on the Misfortunes of their Countrymen. But you, Sir, I may tell it you without Flattery, have grafted on this natural Commieration, and rais'd it to a Nobler Vertue: As you have been pleas'd to honour me, for a long time, with ome part of your Eteem and your good Will; o in particular, ince the late Revolution, you have increas'd the Proofs of your kindnes to me; and not uffer'd the difference of Opinions, which produce uch Hatred and Enmity in the brutal Part of Human kind, to remove you from the ettled Bais of your good Nature and good Sence. This Noblenes of yours, had it been exercis'd on an Enemy, had certainly been a Point of Honour, and as uch I might have jutly recommended it to the World: But that of contancy to your former Choice, and the puruance of your firt Favours, are Vertues not overcommon amongt Englih Men. All things of Honour have, at bet, omewhat of Otentation in them, and Self-love; there is a Pride of doing more than is expected from us, and more than others would have done. But to proceed in the ame Tract of Goodnes, Favour, and Protection, is to hew that a Man is acted by a thorough Principle: It carries omewhat of Tendernes in it, which is Humanity in a Heroical Degree; 'tis a kind of unmoveable good Nature; a word which is commonly Depis'd, becaue it is o eldom Practis'd. But after all, 'tis the mot generous Vertue, oppos'd to the mot degenerate Vice, which is
that of Ruggednes and Harhnes to our Fellow Creatures.

'Tis upon this knowledge of you, Sir, that I have choen you, with your permiion, to be the Patron of this Poem. And, as ince this wonderful Revolution, I have begun with the bet Pattern of Humanity, the Earl of Leiceter; I hall continue to follow the ame Method, in all, to whom I hall Addres; and endeavour to pitch on uch only, as have been pleas'd to own me in this Ruin of my mall Fortune; who, though they are of a contrary Opinion themelves, yet blame not me for adhering to a lot Caue; and judging for my elf, what I cannot chue but judge; o long as I am a patient Sufferer, and no diturber of the Government. Which, if it be a evere Penance, as a great Wit has told the World, 'tis at leat enjoyn'd me by my elf: And Sancho Panca, as much a Fool as I, was oberv'd to dicipline his Body, no farther than he found he could endure the mart.

You ee, Sir, I am not entertaining you, like Ovid, with a Lamentable Epitle from Pontus; I uffer no more, than I can eaily undergo; and o long as I enjoy my Liberty, which is the Birth-right of an Englih Man, the ret hall never go near my Heart. The Merry Philoopher, is more to my Humour than the Melancholick; and I find no dipoition in my elf to Cry, while the mad World is daily upplying me with uch Occaions of Laughter. The more reaonable ort of my Countrymen, have hewn o much favour to this Piece, that they give me no doubt of their Protection for the future.

As you, Sir, have been pleas'd to follow the Example of their Goodnes, in favouring me: So give me leave to ay, that I follow yours in this Dedication, to a Peron of a different Perwaion. Though I mut confes withal, that I have had a former Encouragement from you for this Addres and the warm Remembrance of your noble Hopitality to me at
Trentham, when ome years a go I viited my Friends and Relations in your Country, has ever ince given me a violent Temptation to this boldnes.

'Tis true, were this Comedy wholly mine, I hould call it a Trifle, and perhaps not think it worth your Patronage; but when the Names of Plautus and Moliere are joyn'd in it; that is, the two greatet Names of Ancient and Modern Comedy, I mut not preume o far on their Reputation, to think their bet and mot unquetion'd Productions can be term'd Little. I will not give you the trouble, of acquainting you what I have added, or alter'd in either of them, o much it may be for the wore; but only that the difference of our Stage from the Roman and the French did o require it. But I am affraid, for my own Interet, the World will too eaily dicover, that more than half of it is mine; and that the ret is rather a lame Imitation of their Excellencies, than a jut Tranlation. 'Tis enough, that the Reader know by you, that I neither deerve nor deire any Applaue from it: If I have perform'd any thing, 'tis the Genius of my Authors that inpir'd me; and if it has pleas'd in Repreentation, let the Actors hare the Praie amongt themelves. As for Plautus and Moliere, they are dangerous People; and I am too weak a Gameter to put my elf into their Form of Play. But what has been wanting on my Part, has been abundantly upplyed by the Excellent Compoition of Mr. Purcell; in whoe Peron we have at length found an Englih-man, equal with the bet abroad. At leat my Opinion of him has been uch, ince his happy and judicious Performances in the late Opera; and the Experience I have had of him, in the etting my Three Songs for this Amphitryon: To all which, and particularly to the Compoition of the Patoral Dialogue, the numerous Quire of Fair Ladies gave o jut an Applaue on the Third Day. I am only orry, for my own ake, that there was one
Star wanting, as Beautiful as any in our Hemiphere; that young Berenice, who is miimploying all her Charms on tupid Country Souls, that can never know the Value of them; and loing the Triumphs, which are ready prepar'd for her in the Court and Town. And yet I know not whether I am o much a loer by her abence; for I have Reaon to apprehend the harpnes of her Judgment, if it were not allay'd with the weetnes of her Nature; and after all, I fear he may come time enough, to dicover a Thouand Imperfections in my Play, which might have pas'd on Vulgar Undertandings. Be pleas'd to ue the Authority of a Father over her, on my behalf; enjoyn her to keep her own Thoughts of Amphitryon to her elf; or at leat not to compare him too trictly with Moliere's. 'Tis true, I have an Interet in this Partiality of hers; but withal, I plead ome ort of Merit for it, in being o Particularly as I am,

closer.signed: Your mot obedient, humble Servant, JOHN DRYDEN.

div.head: PROLOGUE TO Amphitryon; or, The Two Soia's.
div.l: THE lab'ring Bee, when his harp Sting is gone,
Forgets his Golden Work, and turns a Drone:
Such is a Satyr, when you take away
That Rage, in which his Noble Vigour lay.
What gain you, by not uffering him to teize ye?
He neither can offend you, now, nor pleae ye.
The Honey-bag, and Venome, lay o near,
That both, together, you reolv'd to tear;
And lot your Pleaure, to ecure your Fear.
How can he how his Manhood, if you bind him
To box, like Boys, with one Hand ty'd behind him?
This is plain levelling of Wit; in which
The Poor has all th' advantage, not the Rich.
The Blockhead tands excus'd, for wanting Sene;
And Wits turn Blockheads in their own defence.
Yet, though the Stages Traffick is undone,
Still Julian's interloping Trade goes on:
Though Satyr on the Theatre you mother,
Yet in Lampoons, you Libel one another.
The firt produces till, a econd Jig;
You whip 'em out, like School-boys, till they gig:
And, with the ame ucces, we Readers gues;
For, ev'ry one, till dwindles to a les.
And much good Malice, is o meanly dret,
That we wou'd laugh, but cannot find the Jet.
If no advice your Rhiming Rage can tay,
Let not the Ladies uffer in the Fray.
Their tender Sex, is priviledg'd from War;
'Tis not like Knights, to draw upon the Fair.
What Fame expect you from o mean a Prize?
We wear no murdring Weapons, but our Eyes.
Our Sex, you know, was after yours deign'd;
The lat Perfection of the Makers mind:
Heav'n drew out all the Gold for us, and left your Dros behind.
Beauty, for Valours bet Reward, He choe;
Peace, after War; and after Toil, Repoe.
Hence ye Prophane; excluded from our ights;
And charm'd by Day, with Honour's vain delights,
Go, make your bet of olitary Nights.
Recant betimes, 'tis prudence to ubmit:
Our Sex, is till your Overmatch, in Wit:
We never fail, with new, uccesful Arts,
To make fine Fools of you; and all your Parts.

div.head: The Scene THEBES.
div.stage: Mercury and Phoebus decend in everal Machines.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.l: KKnow you the Reaon of this preent Summons?
'Tis neither Council-day, nor is this Heav'n;
What Buines has our Jupiter on Earth?
Why more at Thebes than any other Place?
And why we two of all the Herd of Gods
Are choen out to meet him in Conult?
They call me God of Widom,
But Mars and Vulcan, the two Fools of Heav'n,
Whoe Wit lyes in their Anvil and their Sword,
Know full as much as I.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: And Venus may know more than both of us,
For 'tis ome Petticoat Affair I gues,
sp.p: I have dicharg'd my Duty; which was to ummon you, Phoebus: we hall know more anon, when the Thunderer comes down. 'Tis our Part to obey our Father; for, to confes the Truth, we two are little better than Sons of Harlots: and if Jupiter had not been pleas'd to take a little pains with our Mothers, intead of being Gods, we might have been a couple of Linck-Boys.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.p: But know you nothing farther, Hermes? What news in Court?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: There has been a devillih Quarrel, I can tell you, betwixt Jupiter and Juno: She threaten'd to ue him in the Spiritual Court, for ome Matrimonial Omiions; and he tood upon his Prerogative. Then he hit him on the Teeth of all his Batards; and your Name and mine were us'd with les reverence than became our Godhips. They were both in their Cups; and at the lat the matter grew o high, that they were ready to have thrown Stars at one anothers Heads.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.p: 'Twas happy for me that I was at my Vocation, driving Day-light about the World; but I had rather tand my Fathers Thunderbolts, than my Step-mothers Railing.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: When the Tongue-battle was over, and the Championes had harnes'd her Peacocks, to go for Samos, and hear the Prayers that were made to her—

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.p: By the way her Worhippers had a bad time on't; he was in a damnable Humour for receiving Petitions—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Jupiter immediately beckons me aide; and charges me, that as oon as ever you had et up your Hores, you and I hou'd meet him here at Thebes: now, putting the Premies together, as dark as it is, methinks I begin to ee Day-light.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.p: As plain as one of my own Beams; he has made him uneaie at home, and he is going to eek his diverion abroad: I ee Heav'n it elf is no priviledg'd Place for happines, if a Man mut carry his Wife along with him.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Tis neither better nor wore, upon my Concience: he is weary of hunting in the pacious Foret of a Wife, and is following his Game incognito, in ome little Purliew here at Thebes; that's many an honet Mans Cae on Earth too, Jove help 'em; as indeed he does to make 'em Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.p: But if o Mercury, then I, who am a Poet, mut indite his Love-letter; and you, who are by Trade a Porter, mut convey it.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No more, he's coming down owe upon us, and hears as far as he can ee too; he's plaguy hot upon the buines, I know it by his hard driving.

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.l: What, you are decanting upon my Actions?
Much good may do you with your Politicks:
All Subjects will be cenuring their Kings.
Well, I confes I am in love; what then?

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.l: Some Mortal, we preume, of Cadmu's Blood:
Some Theban Beauty; ome new Semele,
Or ome Europa.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I'll ay that for my Father, he's contant to an handom Family: He knows when they have a good mack with 'em; and nuffs up Incene o avourly, when 'tis offer'd him by a fair Hand.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Well, my familiar Sons, this awcy Carriage
I have deerv'd; for he who truts a Secret
Makes his own Man his Mater.
I read your Thoughts;
Therefore you may as afely peak as think.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Mine was a very homely Thought; I was conidering into what form your Almighty-hip would be pleas'd to transform your elf to night. Whether you wou'd fornicate in the Shape of a Bull, or a Ram, or an Eagle, or a Swan: What Bird or Beat you wou'd pleae to honour, by trangreing your own Laws, in his likenes; or in hort, whether you wou'd recreate your elf in Feathers, or in Leather?

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.l: Any diguie to hide the King of Gods.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I know your Malice, Phoebus, you wou'd ay
That when a Monarch ins it hou'd be ecret;
To keep exterior how of Sanctity;
Maintain Repect, and cover bad Example:
For Kings and Priets are in a manner bound
For Reverence ake, to be cloe Hypocrites.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.l: But what neceitates you to this Love,
Which you confes a Crime, and yet commit?
For to be ecret makes not in the les:
'Tis only hidden from the vulgar view:
Maintains, indeed, the Reverence due to Princes,
But not abolves the Concience from the Crime.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I Love, becaue 'twas in the Fates I hou'd.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.l: With reverence be it poke, a bad excue:
Thus every wicked Act in Heav'n or Earth,
May make the ame defence; but what is Fate?
Is it a blind contingence of Events?
Or ure neceity of Caues linck'd,
That mut produce Effects? or is't a Pow'r
That orders all things by uperior VVill,
Foreees his VVork, and works in that foreight?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Fate is, what I
By vertue of Omnipotence have made it:
And pow'r Omnipotent can do no wrong:
Not to my elf, becaue I will'd it o:
Nor yet to Men, for what they are is mine.
This night I will enjoy Amphitryon's VVife:
For, when I made her, I decreed her uch
As I hou'd pleae to love. I wrong not him
VVhoe VVife he is; for I reerv'd my Right,
To have her while he pleas'd me; that once pat,
She hall be his again.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Here's Omnipotence with a Vengeance, to make a Man a Cuckold, and yet not to do him wrong. Then I find, Father Jupiter, that when you made Fate, you had the wit to contrive a Holy-day for your elf now and then. For you Kings never Enact a Law, but you have a kind of an Eye to your own Prerogative.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.l: If there be no uch thing as right and wrong,
Of an Eternal Being, I have done—
But if there be.—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Peace, thou diputing Fool:
Learn this; if thou could't comprehend my ways,
Then thou wert Jove, not I: yet, thus far know,
That, for the good of Human-kind, this Night
I hall beget a future Hercules;
Who hall redres the Wrongs of injur'd Mortals,
Shall conquer Monters, and reform the World.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Ay, Brother Phoebus; and our Father made all thoe Monters for Hercules to Conquer, and contriv'd all thoe Vices on purpoe for him to reform too, there's the Jeat on't.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.p: Since Arbitrary Pow'r will hear no Reaon, 'tis Widom to be ilent.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why that's the Point; this ame Arbitrary Power is a knock-down Argument; 'tis but a Word and a Blow; now methinks our Father peaks out like an honet bare-fac'd God, as he is; he lays the tres in the right Place, upon abolute Dominion: I confes if he had been a Man, he might have been a Tyrant, if his Subjects durt have call'd him to account: But you Brother Poebus, are but a meer Country Gentleman, that never comes to Court; that are abroad all day on Hore-back, making Viits about the World; are drinking all Night, and in your Cups are till rayling at the Government: O thee Patriots, thee bumpkin Patriots, are a very illy ort of Animal.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: My preent Purpoe and Deign you heard;
T' enjoy Amphitryon's Wife, the fair Alcmena:
You two mut be ubervient to my Love.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No more of your Grumbletonian Morals Brother; there's Preferment coming, be advis'd and Pimp dutifully.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Amphitryon, the brave Theban General,
Has overcome his Countreys Foes in Fight;
And in a ingle Duel lain their King:
His Conquering Troops are eager on their march
Returning home; while their young General
More eager to review his beauteous Wife,
Pots on before, wing'd with impetuous Love,
And, by to morrows dawn, will reach this Town.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That's but hort warning, Father Jupiter: having made no former advances of Courthip to her, you have need of your Omnipotence, and all your Godhip, if you mean to be before hand with him.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.l: Then how are we to be employ'd this Evening;
Time's precious, and thee Summer Nights are hort;
I mut be early up to light the World.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: You hall not rie; there hall be no to morrow;

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Then the VVorld's to be at an end, I find.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.l: Or ele a Gap in Nature, of a Day.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: A day, will well be lot to buie Man:
Night hall continue leep, and care hall ceae.
So, many Men hall live, and live in peace,
VVhom Sun-hine had betray'd to envious Sight,
And Sight to udden Rage, and Rage to Death.
Now, I will have a night for love and me;
A long luxurious Night, fit for a God
To quench and empty his immortal Heat.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I'll lay on the VVomans ide for all that; that he hall love longet to night, in pight of your Omnipotence.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.l: I hall be curs'd by all the lab'ring Trades,
That early rie, but you mut be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: No matter for the cheating part of Man;
They have a day's in les to anwer for.

sp.speaker: Phoeb.
sp.l: When wou'd you have me wake?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Why, when Jove goes to leep: when I have finih'd,
Your Brother Mercury hall bring you word.
Now, Hermes, I mut take Amphitryon's form,
T' enjoy his Wife;
Thou mut be Soia, this Amphitryon's lave;
Who, all this Night, is travelling to Thebes,
To tell Alcmena of her Lords approach;
And bring her joyful news of Victory.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: But why mut I be Soia?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Dull God of Wit, thou Statue of thy elf!
Thou mut be Soia, to keep out Soia:
Who, by his entrance, might dicover Jove,
Diturb my Pleaures, raie unruly Noie,
And o ditract Alcmena's tender Soul,
She wou'd not meet my warmth, when I diolve
Into her Lap, nor give down half her Love.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Let me alone; I'll cudgel him away:
But I abhor o Villanous a hape.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Take it; I charge thee on thy Duty, take it:
Nor dare to lay it down, till I command.
I cannot bear a moments los of Joy.
Look up, the Night is in her ilent Chariot;
And rouling jut o're Thebes: bid her drive lowly,
Or make a double turn about the World;
While I drop Jove, and take Amphitryon's Dres,
To be the greater, while I eem the les.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Madam Night, a good Even to you: fair and oftly, I beeech you Madam: I have a word or two to you, from no les a God than Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: O, my nimble finger'd God of Theft, what make you here on Earth, at this uneaonable hour? what Bankers Shop is to be broken open to Night? or what Clippers, and Coiners, and Conpirators, have been invoking your Deity for their aitance.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Faith none of thoe Enormities; and yet I am till in my Vocation: for you know I am a kind of Jack of all Trades: at a word, Jupiter is indulging his Genius to night, with a certain noble ort of Recreation, call'd Wenching: The truth on't is, Adultery is its proper name.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Jupiter wou'd do well to tick to his Wife Juno.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: He has been marry'd to her above thee hundred years; and that's long enough in concience to tick to one Woman.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: She's his Siter too, as well as his Wife; that's a double tye of affection to her.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Nay, if he made bold with his own Fleh and Blood, 'tis likely he will not pare his Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: If I were his Wife, I would raie a Rebellion againt him, for the violation of my Bed.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Thou art mitaken, Old Night: his Wife cou'd raie no faction: all the Deities in Heaven wou'd take the part of the Cuckold-making God; for they are all given to the Fleh mot damnably. Nay the very Goddees wou'd tickle in the caue of Love, 'tis the way to be Popular to Whore and Love. For what dot thou think old Saturn was depos'd, but that he was cold and impotent; and made no court to the fair Ladies. Pallas and Juno themelves as chate as they are, cry'd hame on him I ay unto thee, Old Night, Wo be to the Monarch that has not the Women on his ide.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Then by your rule, Mercury, A King who wou'd live happily, mut debauch his whole Nation of Women.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: As far as his ready Money will go, I mean; for Jupiter himelf can't pleae all of 'em. But this is beide my preent Commiion; He has ent me to will and require you to make a winging long Night for him: for he hates to be tinted in his Pleaures.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Tell him plainly, I'll rather lay down my Commiion: What wou'd he make a Bawd of me?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Poor Ignorant! why he meant thee for a Bawd when he firt made thee. What art thou good for, but to be a Bawd? Is not Day light better for Mankind, I mean as to any other ue, but only for Love and Fornication? Thou hat been a Bawd too, a Reverend, Primitive, Original Bawd, from the firt hour of thy Creation! and all the laudable actions of Love, have been committed under thy Mantle. Prithee for what dot thou think that thou art worhipp'd?

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Why for my Stars and Moonhine.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That is, for holding a Candle to iniquity: but if they were put out, thou wou'dt be double worhipt, by the willing bahful Virgins.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Then for my quiet, and the weetnes of my leep.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, for thy weet waking all the Night: for leep comes not upon Lovers till thou art vanih'd.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: But it will be againt Nature, to make a long Winters Night at Midummer.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Trouble not your elf for that: Phoebus is order'd to make a hort Summers Day to morrow: o in four and twenty Hours all will be at rights again.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Well, I am ediied by your dicoure; and my comfort is, that whatever work is made, I ee nothing.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: About your buines then: put a Spoke into your Chariot Wheels, and order the Seven Stars to halt, while I put my elf into the habit of a Serving man; and dres up a fale So ••• , to wait upon a fale Amphitryon. Good night, Night.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: My ervice to Jupiter. Farewell Mercury.

div.head: Scene II.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: WHy was I marri'd to the Man I love!
For, had he been indifferent to my choice,
Or had been hated, abence had been pleaure:
But now I fear for my Amphitryon's life:
At home, in private, and ecure from War,
I am amidt an Hoat of armed foes:
Sutaining all his Cares, pierc'd with his Wounds,
And if he falls (which O ye Gods aver.)
Am, in Amphitryon lain! wou'd I were there,
And he were here; o might we change our Fates;
That he might grieve for me, and I might die for him!

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Good news, good news, Madam, O uch admirable news, that if I kept it in a moment, I hou'd burt with it!

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Is it from the Army?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No matter.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: From Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No matter, neither.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Anwer me, I charge thee, if thy good news be any thing relating to my Lord: if it be, aure thy elf of a Reward.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, now you ay omething to the matter: you know the buines of a poor Waiting-woman, here upon Earth, is to be craping up omething againt a rainy Day, call'd the Day of Marriage: every one in our own Vocation: but what matter is it to me if my Lord has routed the Enemies, if I get nothing of their poils?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Say, is my Lord victorious?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Why he is victorious; indeed I pray'd devoutly to Jupiter for a Victory; by the ame token, that you hou'd give me ten pieces of Gold, if I brought you news of it.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: They are thine; uppoing he be afe too.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Nay that's a new bargain; for I vow'd to Jupiter, that then you hou'd give me ten Pieces more: but I do undertake for my Lord's afety: if you will pleae to dicharge his Godhip Jupiter of the debt, and take it upon you to pay.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: When he returns in afety, Jupiter and I will pay your Vow.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And I am ure I articled with Jupiter, that if I brought you news, that my Lord was upon return, you hou'd grant me one mall favour more, that will cot you nothing.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Make hate, thou Torturer; is my Amphitryon upon return?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Promie me that I hall be your bedfellow to Night, as I have been ever ince my Lord's abence,—unles I hall be pleas'd to releae you of your word.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: That's a mall requet, 'tis granted.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: But wear by Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: But why by Jupiter?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Becaue he's the greatet: I hate to deal with one of your little baffling Gods that can do nothing, but by permiion: but Jupiter can winge you off; if you wear by him, and are forworn.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I wear by Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then I believe he is Victorious, and I know he is afe: for I look'd through the Key-hole, and aw him knocking at the Gate; and I had the Concience to let him cool his Heels there.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: And wou'dt thou not open to him! Oh thou Traitres!

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, I was a little wier: I left Soia's Wife to let him in: for I was reolv'd to bring the news, and make my penny-worths out of him; as time hall how.

div.stage: Enter Jupiter, in the hape of Amphitryon, with Soia's Wife, Bromia.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: O let me live for ever on thoe Lips!—
The Nectar of the Gods, to thee is tateles.
I wear, that were I Jupiter, this Night
I wou'd renounce my Heav'n, to be Amphitryn.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Then, not to wear beneath Amphitryon's Oath,
(Forgive me Juno if I am profane)
I wear, I wou'd be what I am this Night;
And be Alcmena, rather than be Juno.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Good my Lord, what's become of my poor Bedfellow, your Man Soia: you keep uch a billing and colling here, to et ones Mouth a watring: what, I ay, though I am a poor Woman, I have a Husband as well as my Lady; and hou'd be as glad as he, of a little honet Recreation.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And what have you done with your old Friend, and my old Sweet-heart, Judge Gripus? has he brought me home a cramd Pure that wels with Bribes: if he be rich, I'll make him welcome, like an honourable Magitrate: but if he has not had the wit to ell Jutice, he judges no Caues in my Court, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: My Lord you tell me nothing of the Battel?
Is Thebes Victorious, are our Foes detroy'd?
For now I find you afe, I hou'd be glad
To hear you were in danger?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: A Man had need be a God, to tand the fury of three talking Women! I think in my Concience I made their Tongues of Thunder.
Bromia pulling him on one ide. I ask'd the firt quetion: anwer me my Lord.
Phaedra pulling him on to'ther ide. Peace, mine's a Lover, and yours is but a Husband: and my Judge is my Lord too; the Title hall take place, and I will be anwer'd.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Soia is afe: Gripus is rich: both coming:
I rode before 'em, with a Lovers hate.—
Was e're poor God o worri'd! but for my Love,
I wih I were in Heav'n again with Juno.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Then I, it eems, am lat to be regarded?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Not o, my Love, but thee obtreperous Tongues
Have natch'd their anwers firt: they will be heard;
And urely Jove wou'd never anwer Pray'r
That Women made, but only to be freed
From their Eternal Noie: make hate to Bed:
There let me tell my Story, in thy Arms;
There in the gentle paues of our Love,
Betwixt our dyings, e're we live again,
Thou halt be told the Battel, and ucces:
Which I hall oft begin, and then break off;
For Love will often interrupt my Tale,
And make o weet confuion in our talk,
That thou halt ask, and I hall anwer things,
That are not of a piece: but, patch'd with Kies,
And Sighs, and Murmurs, and imperfect Speech;
And Nonence hall be Eloquent, in Love.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: My Lord is very hot upon't: this abence is a great Friend to us poor neglected Wives; it makes us new again.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I am the Fool of Love; and find within me
The fondnes of a Bride, without the fear.
My whole Deires and Wihes are in you.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: My Ladies Eyes are pinking to Bedward too; Now is She to look very leepy, counterfeiting yauning, but She hall ask me leave firt.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Great Juno, thou whoe holy care preides
Over the Nuptial Bed, pour all thy Bleings
On this Aupicious Night.

sp.speaker: Jup:
sp.l: Juno may grudge: for he may fear a Rival,
In thoe bright Eyes; but Jupiter will grant,
And doubly bles this Night.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: But Jupiter hou'd ask my leave firt, were he here in Peron.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Bromia, prepare the Bed:
The tedious journey has dipos'd my Lord,
To eek his needful ret.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, Madam; the poor Gentleman mut needs be weary; and therefore, 'twas not ill contriv'd that he mut lie alone to Night, to recruit himelf with leep, and lay in enough for to morrow Night, when you may keep him waking.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I mut confes I made a kind of promie.—

sp.speaker: Phaedra,
sp.p: A kind of promie, do you call it? I ee you wou'd fain be coming off: I am ure you wore to me, by Jupiter, that I hou'd be your Bedfellow, and I'll accue you to him too, the firt Prayers I make: And I'll pray a purpoe too, that I will, though I have not pray'd to him this even Years.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: O, the malicious Hilding!

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I did wear indeed, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Forwear thy elf; for Jupiter but laughs
At Lovers Perjuries.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: The more hame for him if he does: there wou'd be a fine God indeed for us Women to worhip, if he laughs when our Sweet-hearts cheat us of our Maiden-heads: No, no, Jupiter is an honeter Gentleman than you make of him.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I'm all on fire; and wou'd not looe this Night,
To be the Mater of the Univere.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, I ee you are on fire: but the Devil a Bucket hall be brought to quench it, without my leave: you may go to Bed, Madam; but you hall ee how Heav'n will bles your Nights work, if you forwear your elf:—Some Fool, ome meer Elder-Brother, or ome blockheadly Hero, Jove, I beeech thee, end her.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Now I cou'd call my Thunder to revenge me,
But that were to confes my elf a God,
And then I lot my Love!—Alcmena, come,
By Heav'n I have a Bridegrooms fervour for thee,
As I had ne'er enjoy'd.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: She has my Oath;
And ure he may releae it if he pleae.—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Why truly Madam, I am not cruel in my nature, to poor ditreed Lovers; for it may be my own cae another day: And therefore, if my Lord pleaes to conider me.—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Any thing, any thing, but name thy wih, and have it.—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Ay, now you ay, any thing, any thing; but you wou'd tell me another tory to morrow Morning. Look you my Lord, here's a Hand open to receive; you know the meaning of it: I am for nothing but the Ready—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Thou halt have all the Treaury of Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Yes when you are Jupiter, to dipoe of it.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I had forgot, and how'd my elf a God;
This Love can make a Fool of Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You have got ome part of the Enemies Spoil I warrant you; I ee a little trifling Diamond upon your Finger; and I am proud enough to think it wou'd become mine too.

sp.speaker: Jupiter,
sp.stage: taking a Ring off his Finger and giving it.
sp.l: Here, take it;
This is a very Woman:
Her Sex is Avarice, and he, in One,
Is all her Sex.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis no matter what you ay of us. What wou'd you have your Mony out of the Treaury, without paying the Officers their Fees? Go, get you together, you naughty Couple, till you are both weary of worrying one another, and then to morrow morning, I hall have another Fee for parting you.

div.stage: [Phaedra goes out before Alcmena with a Light.

sp.speaker: Jupiter olus.
sp.l: Why now I am, indeed, the Lord of all:
For what's to be a God, but to enjoy?
Let human-kind their Sovereign's leiure waite;
Love is, this Night, my great Affair of State:
Let this one Night, of Providence be void:
All Jove, for once, is on himelf employ'd.
Let unregarded Altars moke in vain;
And let my Subjects praie me, or complain.
Yet, if betwixt my Intervals of blis,
Some am'rous Youth his Oraions addres,
His Pray'r is in a happy hour preferr'd:
And when Jove loves, a Lover hall be heard.

div.stage: Soia with a Dark-Lanthorn: Mercury, in Soia's hape, with a Dark-Lanthorn alo.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: WAS not the Devil in my Mater, to end me out in this dreadful dark Night, to bring the news of his Victory to my Lady? and was not I poes'd with ten Devils, for going on his errand, without a Convoy for the afeguard of my Peron? Lord, how am I melted into Sweat with fear! I am diminih'd of my natural weight, above two Stone. I hall not bring half my elf home again, to my poor Wife and Family: I have been in an Ague fit, ever ince hut of Evening; what with the fright of Trees by the High-way, which look'd maliciouly like Thieves, by Moon-hine: and what with Bulruhes by the River-ide, that hak'd like Spears, and Lances at me. Well! the greatet Plague of a Serving man, is to be hir'd to ome great Lord! They care not what drudgery they put upon us, while they lie lolling at their Eae a Bed, and tretch their lazy Limbs, in expectation of the Whore which we are fetching for them.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: He is but a poor Mortal, that uffers this! bur I, who am a God, am degraded to a foot Pimp; a Waiter without Doors; a very civil employment for a Deity!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: The better ort of 'em will ay, Upon my Honour, at every word yet ask 'em for our Wages, and they plead the Priviledge of their Honour, and will not pay us; nor let us take our Priviledge of the Law upon them. Thee are a very hopeful ort of Patriots, to tand up as they do for Liberty and Property of the Subject: there's Concience for you!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: This Fellow, has omething of the Republican Spirit in him.

sp.speaker: Soia
sp.p:
Stay; this methinks hou'd be our Houe: and I hou'd thank the Gods, now, for bringing me afe home: but I think I had as good let my Devotions alone, till I have got the reward for my good news, and then thank 'em once for all: for if I praie 'em, before I am afe within
Doors, ome damn'd Matiff Dog may come out, and worry me; and then my thanks are thrown away upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Thou art a wicked Rogue, and wilt have thy Bargain before hand: Therefore thou get't not into the Houe this Night; and thank me accordingly as I ue thee.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Now am I to give my Lady an Account of my Lord's Victory; 'tis good to exercie my Parts before hand, and file my Tongue into eloquent Expreions, to tickle her Ladyhips imagination.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good! and here's the God of Eloquence to judge of thy Oration.

sp.speaker: Soia,
sp.p: This Lanthorn, for once, hall be my Lady: becaue he is the Lamp of all Beauty and Perfection.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, Rogue, 'tis thy Lord is the Lanthorn by this time, or Jupiter is turn'd fumbler.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Then thus I make my Addrees to her: (Bowes) Madam, my Lord has choen me out, as the mot Faithful, though the mot unworthy of his followers; to bring your Ladihip this following Account of our glorious Expedition. Then he—O my poor Soia, (in a hrill Tone) how am I overjoy'd to ee thee! She can ay no les:—Madam, you do me too much Honour, and the World will envy me this glory:—well anwer'd on my ide.—And how does my Lord Amphitryon?—Madam, he always does like a Man of Courage, when he is call'd by Honour.—There I think I nick'd it.—But when will he return?—As oon as poibly he can: but not o oon as his impatient Heart cou'd wih him with your Ladyhip.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: When Thebes is an Univerity, thou deervet to be their Orator.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: But what does he do, and what does he ay? Prethee tell me omething more of him.—He always ays les than he does, Madam: and his Enemies have found it to their cot.—Where the Devil did I learn thee Elegancies and Gallantries?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: So; he has all the natural Endowments of a Fop; and only wants the Education!

sp.speaker: Soia,
sp.p: What is the Devil in the Night! he's as long as two Nights: the even Stars are jut where they were even Hours ago! high Day—high Night, I mean, by my favour. What has Phoebus been playing the Good-fellow, and overlept himelf, that he forgets his duty to us Mortals?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How familiarly the Raskal treats us Gods! but I hall make him alter his tone immediately.

div.stage: [Mercury comes nearer, and tands jut before him.

sp.speaker: Soia,

stage.U: eeing him, and tarting back, aide.

sp.p: How now? what do my Eyes dazle, or is my dark Lanthorn fale to me! is not that a Giant before our Door? or a Ghot of ome body lain in the late Battel? if he be, 'tis unconcionably done, to fright an honet Man thus, who never drew Weapon wrathfully in all my life!—Whatever Wight he be, I am devilihly afraid, that's certain: but 'tis dicretion to keep my own Counel: I'll ing, that I may eem Valiant.

div.stage: [Soia ings; and as Mercury peaks, by little and little drops his Voice.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What awoy Companion is this, that deafens us with his hoare Voice? what Midnight Ballad-inger have we here? I hall teach the Villain to leave off Catterwawling.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I wou'd I had Courage, for his ake; that I might teach him to call my inging Catterwawling, an Illiterate Rogue; an Enemy to the Mues and to Muick.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: There is an ill avour that offends my Notrils; and it wafteth this way?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: He has melt me out my fear has betray'd me into this avour.—I am a dead Man: the bloody Villain is at his fee, fa, fum, already.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Stand, who goes there?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: A Friend.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What Friend?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why a Friend to all the World that will give me leave to live peaceably.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I defie Peace and all its Works; my Arms are out of exercie, they have maul'd no body thee three days: I long for an honourable Occaion to pound a Man; and lay him a leep at the firt Buffet.

sp.speaker: Soia
sp.p: That wou'd almot do me a kindnes; for I have been kept wakeing, without tipping one wink of leep thee three Nights.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Of what Quality are you, Fellow?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why I am a Man, Fellow,—Courage Soia—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What kind of Man?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why a Two-leg'd Man, What Man hou'd I be?— (Aide)—I mut bear up to him, he may prove as errant a Milkop as my elf.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Thou art a Coward I warrant thee, do not I hear thy Teeth chatter in thy Head?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Ay, ay, that's only a ign they wou'd be napping at thy Noe.— (Aide)—Bles me, what an Arm and Fit he has, with great Thumbs too: and Gols and Knuckle-bones of a very Butcher.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Sirrah, from whence come you, and whither go you? anwer me directly, upon pain of Aaination.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I am coming from whence I came, and am going whither I go; that's directly home—though this is omewhat an uncivil manner of proceeding, at the firt ight of a Man, let me tell you.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Then to begin our better Acquaintance, let me firt make you a mall Preent of this box o' the Ear.—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: If I were as cholerick a Fool as you now, here wou'd be fine work betwixt us two; but I am a little better bred, than to diturb the leeping Neighbourhood, and o good night Friend.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Hold Sir; you and I mut not part o eaily; once more, whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why I am going as fat as I can, to get out of the reach of your Clutches: let me but only knock at that Door there.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What buines have you at that Door, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: This is our Houe; and when I am got in, I'll tell you more.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Whoe Houe is this, Sawcines, that you are o familiar with, to call it ours?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: 'Tis mine, in the firt place; and next, my Maters; for I lye in the Garrret, and he lyes under me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Have your Mater and you no Names, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: His Name is Amphitryon, hear that and tremble.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What, my Lord General?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: O, has his Name mollify'd you! I have brought you down a Peg lower already, Friend.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And your Name is—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Lord, Friend, you are o very troubleom—What hou'd my Name be but Soia?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How, Soia, ay you? how long have you taken up that Name, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Here's a fine quetion: why I never took it up Friend, it was born with me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What was your Name born, Soia? take this Remembrance for that Lye.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Hold Friend, you are o very flippant with your Hands, you won't hear Reaon: What offence has my Name done you, that you hou'd beat me for it? S. O. S. I. A. They are as civil, honet, harmles Letters, as any are in the whole Alphabet.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I have no quarrel to the Name, but that 'tis e'en too good for you, and 'tis none of yours.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: What am not I Soia, ay you?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I hould think you are omewhat merrily dipos'd, if you had not beaten me, in uch ober adnes. You wou'd perwade me out of my Heathen Name, would you?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Say you are Soia again at your Peril, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I dare ay nothing, but Thought is free; but whatever I am call'd, I am Amphitryon's Man, and the firt Letter of my Name is S too. You had bet tell me that my Mater did not end me home to my Lady, with news of his Victory?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I ay he did not.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, Friend, one of us two is horribly giv'n to lying—but I do not ay which of us, to avoid Contention.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I ay, my Name is Soia, and yours is not.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I wou'd you cou'd make good your words, for then I hou'd not be beaten, and you hou'd.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I find you wou'd be Soia if you durt—but if I catch you thinking o—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I hope I may think I was Soia; and I can find no difference between my former elf, and my preent elf; but that I was plain Soia before; and now I am lac'd Soia.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Take this, for being o impudent to think o.

sp.speaker: Soia
sp.p: Truce a little, I beeech thee! I wou'd be a Stock or a Stone now by my good will, and wou'd not think at all, for elf preervation. But will you give me leave to argue the Matter fairly with you? and promie me to depoe that Cudgel, if I can prove my elf to be that Man that I was before I was beaten?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Well, proceed in afety; I promie you I will not beat you.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: In the firt Place then, is not this Town cal'd Thebes?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Uundoubtedly.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: And is not this Houe Amphitryon's?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Who denyes it?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I thought you wou'd have denyed that too? for all hangs upon a String. Remember then, that thoe two preliminary Articles are already granted. In the next place, did not the foreaid Amphitryon beat the Teleboans, kill their King Pterelas, and end a certain Servant, meaning ome Body, that for ake-ake hall be nameles, to bring a Preent to his Wife, with news of his Victory, and of his Reolution to return to morrow?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: This is all true, to a very little; but who is that certain Servant, there's all the quetion?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Is it Peace or War betwixt us?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I dare not wholly trut that abominable Cudgel; but 'tis a certain Friend of yours and mine; that had a certain Name before he was beaten out of it; but if you are a Man that depend not altogether upon force and brutality, but omewhat alo upon Reaon, now do you bring better Proofs that you are that ame certain Man; and in order to it, anwer me to certain Quetions.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I ay I am Soia, Amphitryon's Man; what reaon have you to urge againt it?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: What was your Fathers Name?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Davus; who was an honet Husbandman, whoe Siters Name was Harpagè, that was married, and dyed in a foreign Country.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: So far you are right, I mut confes; and your Wife's Name is.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Bromia, a devilih Shrew of her Tongue, and a Vixon of her Hands; that leads me a mierable Life; keeps me to hard duty a Bed; and beats me every Morning when I have rien from her ide, without having firt—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I undertand you; by many a orrowful Token; this mut be I.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I was once taken upon upicion of Burglary, and was whipt through Thebes, and branded for my pains.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Right me again; but if you are I, as I begin to upect; that whipping and branding might have been pat over in ilence, for both our Credits.—And yet now I think on't, if I am I, (as I am I) he cannot be I. All thee Circumtances he might have heard; but I will now interrogate him upon ome private Paages—What was the Preent that Amphitryon ent by you or me, no matter which of us, to his Wife Alcmena?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: A Buckle of Diamonds, coniting of five large Stones.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: And where are they now?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: In a Cae, eal'd with my Maters Coat of Arms.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: This is prodigious, I confes; but yet 'tis nothing now I think on't, for ome fale Brother may have reveal'd it to him. (Aide) But I have another Quetion to ask you, of omewhat that pas'd only but wixt my elf and me; if you are Soia, what were you doing in the heat of Battel?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What a wie Man hou'd, that has a repect for his own Peron. I ran into our Tent, and hid my elf amongt the Baggage.

sp.speaker: Soia
sp.p: Such another cutting Anwer, and I mut provide my elf of another name. (To him.) And how did you pas your time in that ame Tent? You need not anwer to every Circumtance o exactly now; you mut lye a little, that I may think you the more me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That cunning hall not erve your turn, to circumvent me out of my name: I am for plain naked Truth:—There tood a Hoghead of old VVine, which my Lord reerv'd for his own drinking.—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: O the Devil! as ure as Death, he mut have hid himelf in that Hoghead, or he cou'd never have known that

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And by that Hoghead, upon the ground, there lay the kind Inviter and Provoker of good drinking—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Nay, now I have caught you; there was neither Inviter nor Provoker, for I was all alone.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: A luty Gammon of—

sp.speaker: Soia
sp.p: Bacon—that word has quite made an end of me:—let me ee,—this mut be I, in pight of me.—but let me view him nearer.

div.stage: (Walks about Mercury with his dark Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What are you walking about me for, with your dark Lanthorn?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: No harm Friend; I am only urveying a parcel of Earth here, that I find we two are about to Bargain for:—He's damnable like me, that's certain Imprimis, there's the Patch upon my Noe, with a Pox to him—Item, a very foolih Face with a long Chin at end on't: Item one Pair of hambling Legs, with two play Feet belonging to them. And—umma totalis, from Head to Foot all my Bodily Apparel.— (To Mercury) Well, you are Soia; there's no denying it; but what am I then? for my Mind gives me, I am ome body till, if I knew but who I were.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: When I have a mind to be Soia no more, then thou mait be Soia again.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I have but one requet more to thee, that, though not as Soia, yet as a tranger, I may go into that Houe, and carry a civil Meage to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No Sirrah; not being Soia, you have no Meage to deliver, nor no Lady in this Houe.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Thou cant not be o barbarous, to let me lye in the Streets all night, after uch a Journey, and uch a beating—and therefore I am reolv'd to knock at the Door in my own defence.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: If you come near the Door, I recal my word, and break off the truce:—and then expect—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: No; The Devil take me if I do expect: I have felt too well what owr Fruit that Crab-tree bears: I'll rather beat it back upon the Hoof to my Lord Amphitryon; to ee if he will acknowledg me for Soia; if he does not, then I am no longer his Slave; there's my Freedom dearly purchas'd with a ore drubbing; if he does acknowledg me, then I am Soia again; o far 'tis tolerably well; but then I hall have a econd drubbing, for an unfortunate Ambaador as I am; and that's intolerable.

I have fobb'd off his Excellency pretty well. Now let him return, and make the bet of his Credentials. I think too I have given Jupiter ufficient time for his Conummation. Oh, he has taken his Cue; and here he comes as leiurely and as lank as if he had empty'd himelf of the bet part of his Almightyhip.

div.head: Scene II.
div.stage: Enter Jupiter leading Alcmena, followed by Phaedra. Pages with Torches before them. Jupiter to the Pages.
div.l: THoe Torches are offenive: tand aloof:
For, though they bles me with thy heav'nly ight,
They may dicloe the Secret I would hide:
The Thebans mut not know I have been here;
Detracting Crowds wou'd blame me that I robb'd
Thee happy Moments from my publick Charge,
To Conecrate to thy deir'd embrace:
And I cou'd wih no Witnes but thy elf;
For thou thy elf art all I wih to pleae.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: So long an abence, and o hort a tay!
What, but one Night! one Night of joy and love,
Cou'd only pay one Night of Cares and Fears;
And all the ret are an uncancell'd Sum!
Cure on this Honour and this publick Fame;
Wou'd you had les of both, and more of Love!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Alcmena I mut go.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Not yet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Indeed I mut.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Indeed you hall not go.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Behold the ruddy Streaks o're yonder Hill,
Thoe are the Bluhes of the breaking Morn,
That kindle Day-light to this neather World:

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: No matter for the Day, it was but made
To number out the Hours of buie Men.
Let 'em be buie till, and till be wretched;
And take their fill of anxious drudging day:
But you and I will draw our Curtains cloe,
Extinguih Day-light, and put out the Sun:
Come back, my Lord, in faith you hall retire.
You have not yet lay long enough in Bed,
To warm your widdow'd Side.

sp.speaker: Phaedra,
sp.p: I find my Lord is an excellent Schoolmater, my Lady is o vvilling to repeat her Leon.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That's a plaguy little Devil; what a roguih Eye he has! I begin to like her trangely; he's the Perquiite of my Place too; for my Ladies Waiting-Woman is the proper Fees of my Lords Chief Gentleman. I have the Priviledg of a God too; I can view her naked through all her Clothes:—Let me ee—Let me ee: I have dicover'd omething that pleaes me already.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Let me not live but thou art all Enjoyment!
So charming and o weet,
That not a Night, but whole Eternity,
Were well employ'd,
To love thy each Perfection as it ought.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I'll bribe you with this kis to tay a while.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: A Bribe indeed that oon will bring me back.
But, to be jut, I mut retore your Bribe.
How I cou'd dwell for ever on thoe Lips!
O I cou'd kis 'em pale with eagernes!
So oft, by Heav'n, and uch a juicy weet,
That ripen'd Peaches have not half the flavour.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Ye niggard Gods! you make our Lives too long:
You fill 'em with Dieaes, Wants and Woes,
And only dah 'em with a little Love;
Sprinkled by Fits, and with a paring Hand:
Count all our Joys, from Childhood ev'n to Age,
They wou'd but make a day of ev'ry year:
Take back your ev'nty years, (the tint of Life)
Or ele be kind, and cram the Quinteence
Of Seav'nty years, into weet Seav'nty days:
For all the ret is flat, inipid Being.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: But yet one Scruple pains me at my parting;
I love o nicely, that I cannot bear
To owe the Sweets of Love which I have tated,
To the ubmiive Duty of a Wife:
Tell me: and ooth my Paion e're I go,
That in the kindet Moments of the Night,
When you gave up your elf to Love and me,
You thought not of a Husband, but a Lover.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: But tell me firt, why you wou'd raie a Bluh upon my Cheeks, by asking uch a Quetion?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I wou'd owe nothing to a Name o dull
As Husband is, but to a Lover all.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: You hou'd have ask'd me then, when Love and Night,
And Privacy, had favour'd your demand.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I ask it now, becaue my tendernes
Surpaes that of Husbands for their Wives.
O that you lov'd like me! then you wou'd find
A thouand, thouand Niceties in Love;
The Common love of Sex to Sex is brutal:
But love refind will fancy to it elf
Millions of gentle Cares, and weet Diquiets;
The being happy is not half the Joy;
The manner of the happines is all!
In me (my charming Mitris) you behold
A Lover that didains a Lawful Title;
Such as of Monarchs to ucceive Thrones:
The Generous Lover holds by force of Arms;
And claims his Crown by Conquet.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Methinks you hou'd be pleas'd, I give you all
A Vertuous and a Modet Wife can give.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: No, no, that very name of Wife and Marriage
Is Poyon to the dearet weets of Love:
To pleae my nicenes you mut eparate
The Lover from his Mortal Foe, the Husband.
Give to the yawning Husband your cold Vertue,
But all your vigorous Warmth, your melting Sighs,
Your amorous Murmurs, be your Lovers part.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I comprehend not what you mean, my Lord,
But only love me till, and love me thus,
And think me uch as bet may pleae your Thought.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: There's Mytery of Love in all I ay:
Farewel; and when you ee your Husband next
Think of your Lover then.

div.stage: Exeunt Jupiter and Alcmena everally: Phaedra follows her.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Now I hou'd follow him; but Love has laid a Lime-twig for me, and made a lame God of me. Yet why hou'd I love this Phoedra? She's Intereed, and a Jilt into the Bargain. Three thouand years hence, there will be a whole Nation of uch Women, in a certain Country that will be call'd France; and there's a Neighbour Iland too, where the Men of that Country will be all Interet. Oh what a precious Generation will that be, which the Men of the Iland hall Propagate out of the Women of the Continent?

(Phaedra re-enters)—And o much for Propheie: for he's here again, and I mut love her in pight of me. And ince I mut, I have this Comfort, that the greatet Wits are commonly the greatet Cullies; becaue neither of the Sexes can be wier than ome certain Parts about 'em will give 'em leave.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Well Soia, and how go Matters?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Our Army is Victorious.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: And my Servant Judge Gripus?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: A Voluptuous Gourmand.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: But has he gotten where withal to be Voluptuous, is he Wealthy?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: He ells Jutice as he ues, fleeces the Rich Rebells, and hangs up the Poor.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Then while he has Money he may make love to me. Has he ent me no Token?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Yes a Kis; and by the ame Token, I am to give it you, as a Remembrance from him.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: How now Impudence! A beggarly Serving-man preume to kis me?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Suppoe I were a God, and hou'd make Love to you?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I wou'd firt be atisfi'd, whether you were a poor God or a rich God.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Suppoe I were Mercury, the God of Merchandie?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: What the God of mall Wares, and Fripperies, of Pedlars and Pilferers?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How the Gipie depies me?

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p:
I had rather you were Plutus the God of Money, or Jupiter in a Golden Shower: there was a God for us Women! he had the Art of making
Love: Dot thou think that Kings, or Gods either, get Mitries by their good Faces? no, 'tis the Gold and the Preents they can make: there's the Prerogative they have over their fair Subjects.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: All this notwithtanding, I mut tell you pretty Phaedra, I am deperately in love with you.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And I mut tell thee, ugly Soia, thou hat not where withal to be in love.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Yes, a poor Man may be in love I hope?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I grant a poor Rogue may be in love, but he can never make love: Alas Soia, thou hat neither Face to invite me, nor Youth to pleae me, nor Gold to bribe me: And Beides all this thou hat a Wife, poor mierable Soia! What ho Bromia!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: O thou merciles Creature, why dot thou conjure up that fpright of a Wife?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: To rid my elf of that Devil of a poor Lover: ince you are o lovingly dipos'd, I'll put you together, to exercie your Fury upon your own Wedlock: What Bromia, I ay, make hat; here's a Veel of yours, full fraighted, that's going off, without paying Duties.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Since thou wilt not let me teal Cutom: She hall have all the Cargo I have gotten in the Wars: but thou mightt have lent me a little Creek to muggle in.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Why, what have you gotten, good Gentleman Soldier, beides a Legion of—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: VVhen the Enemy was rowted, I had the plundering of a Tent.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: That's to ay, a Houe of Canvas, with moveables of Straw; make hate Bromia—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But it was the Generals own Tent.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You durt not fight I'm certain; and therefore came lat in, when the rich Plunder was gone before hand.—will you come, Bromia?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Prithee do not call o lowd:—A great Goblet that holds a Gallon.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Of what was that Goblet made? anwer quickly, for I am jut calling very loud—Bro.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Of beaten Gold. Now call a loud, if thou dot not like the Mettal.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Bromia.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That truts in this Fahion, with his Arms a kimbo, like a City Magitrate: and a great bouncing Belly, like an Hotes with Child of a Kilderkin of VVine. Now what ay you to that Preent, Phaedra?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: VVhy I am conidering—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: VVhat I prithee?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: VVhy, how to divide the Buines equally; to take the Gift, and refue the Giver. thou art o damnably ugly and o old.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Now the Devil take Jupiter, or conining me to this ungodly hape to day!
But Gripus is as old and as ugly too.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p:
But Gripus is a Peron of Quality, and my Ladies Uncle, and if he marries me. I hall take place of my Lady. Hark, your Wife! he has ent
her Tongue before her. I hear the Thunderclap already: there's a torm approaching.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Yes, of thy Brewing, I thank thee for it: O how I hou'd hate thee now if I cou'd leave loving thee!

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Not a word of the dear Golden Goblet, as you hope for—you know what, Soia.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You give me Hope then—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Not abolutely Hope neither: but Gold is a great Cordial, in love matters; and the more you apply of it, the better.— [Aide.] I am honet, that's certain; but when I weigh my honety againt the Goblet, I am not quite reolv'd on which ide the Scale will turn.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Farewell Phaedra; remember me to my Wife, and tell her—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Tell her, what Traytor! that you are going away without eeing her.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That I am doing my Duty, and following my Mater.

p.U: o brisk too! your Mater did his Duty to my Lady before he parted: He cou'd leave his Army in the lurch, and come galloping home at Midnight, to have a lick at the Honey-pot; and teal to Bed as quietly as any Moue, I warrant you: My Mater knew what belong'd to a marri'd life; but you, Sirrah.—You Trencher-carrying Raskal, you wore than Dunghill-Cock; that tood clapping your Wings and crowing without Doors, when you hou'd have been at root, you Villain.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Hold your peace, Dame Partlet, and leave your Cackling: My Mater charg'd me to tand Centry without Doors.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: My Mater! I dare wear thou bely't him, My Maters more a Gentleman than to lay uch an unreaonable command upon a poor ditreed marri'd Couple, and after uch an abence too. No, there's no comparion between my Mater and thee, thou Sneaksby.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No more than there is betwixt my Lady and you, Bromia. You and I have had our time in a civil way, Spoue, and much good love has been betwixt us: but we have been married fifteen Years, I take it: and that hoighty toighty buines ought, in Concience, to be over.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Marry come up, My awcy Companion! I am neither old, nor ugly enough to have that aid to me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But will you hear reaon, Bromia? My Lord and my Lady are yet in a manner Bride and Bridegroom; they are in Honey Moon till: do but think in decency what a Jet it wou'd be to the Family, to ee two Venerable old married People, lying nug in a Bed together, and ighing out fine tender things to one another!

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: How now, Traytor, dar't thou maintain that I am pat the Age of having fine things aid to me?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Not o, my Dear: but certainly I am pat the Age of a aying 'em.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Thou deerv't not to be yok'd with a Woman of Honour, as I am, thou perjur'd Villain.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
Ay, you are too much a Woman of Honour, to my orrow: many a poor Husband wou'd be glad to compound for les Honour in his Wife, and
more quiet. Prethee be but honet and continent in thy Tongue, and do thy wort with every thing ele about thee.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Thou wou'dt have a Woman of the Town, wou'dt thou! to be always peaking my Husband fair, to make him diget his Cuckoldom more eaily: wou'dt thou be a Wittol, with a vengeance to thee? I am reolv'd I'll coure thy Hide, for that word.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Thou wilt not trike thy Lord, and Husband, wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Since thou wilt none of the Meat, 'tis but jutice to give thee the batings of the Ladle.
Mercury running about. aide. Was ever poor Deity o Henpeck'd as I am! nay, then 'tis time to charm her aleep with my enchanted Rod—before I am digrac'd or ravih'd.—

div.stage: [Plucks out his Caduceus and trikes her upon the Shoulder with it.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: What, art thou rebelling againt thy annointed Wife? I'll make thee—how now—What, has the Rogue bewitch'd me! I grow dull and tupid on the udden—I can neither tir Hand nor Foot—I am jut like him; I have lot the ue of all my—Members— [yawning.]—I can't o much as wag my Tongue—neither, and that's the lat live—ing part about a—Woman— [falls down.

sp.speaker: Mercury
sp.p: Lord what have I uffer'd, for being but a counterfeit marri'd Man one day! If ever I come to this Houe, as a Husband again—then—and yet that then, was a lye too—For while I am in love with this young Gipie, Phoedra, I mut return—But lie thou there, thou Type of Juno: thou that want't nothing of her Tongue, but the immortality. If Jupiter ever let thee et Foot in Heaven, Juno will have a rattling Second of thee; and there will never be a fair Day in Heaven or Earth after it.
sp.l: For two uch Tongues, will break the Poles aunder;
And, hourly colding, make perpetual Thunder.

div.head: Act III.
Scene,

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: NOw Sirrah, follow me into the Houe, thou halt be convinc'd at thy own cot, Villain! What horrible lyes hat thou told me! uch improbabilities, uch tuff, uch nonence!—that the Monter with two long Horns, that frighted the great King, and the Devil at the Stone-cutters, are Truths to thee!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I am but a Slave, and you are Mater; and a poor Man is always to lye, when a rich Man is pleas'd to contradict him: but as ure as this is our Houe—

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: So ure 'tis thy place of Execution. Thou art not made for lying neither.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: That's certain: for all my Neighbours ay I have an honet Face; or ele they wou'd never call me Cuckold, as they do.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I mean thou hat not wit enough to make a lye, that will hang together: thou hat et up a Trade, that thou hat not Stock enough to manage: O that I had but a Crab-tree Cudgel for thy ake!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: How, a Cudgel, aid you! the Devil take Jupiter for inventing that heard-hearted, merciles, knobby Wood.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: The bitternes is yet to come: thou hat had but a half Doe of it.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I was never good at wallowing Phyick: and my Stomach wambles at the very thought of it; but, if I mut have a econd beating, in concience let me trip firt, that I may how you the black and blue treaks upon my Sides and Shoulders. I am ure I uffer'd them in your ervice.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: To what purpoe wou'dt thou how them?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Why to the purpoe that you may not trike me upon the ore places: and that as he beat me lat Night cros-ways, o you wou'd pleae to beat me long-ways, to make clean work on't, that at leat my Skin may look like Checquer-work.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: This requet is too reaonable to be refus'd; but, that all things may be done in order, tell me over again the ame tory, with all the circumtances of thy Commiion: that a blow may follow in due form for every lye. To Repetition Rogue, to Repetition.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: No, it hall be all a lye if you pleae, and I'll eat my Words to ave my Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Ay, Sirrah, now you find you are to be diproved: but 'tis too late: to Repetition, Rogue, to Repetition.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: With all my heart, to any Repetition but the Cudgel: but, wou'd you be pleas'd to anwer me one civil quetion? Am I to ue Complaiance to you, as to a great Peron, that will have all things aid your own way; or am I to tell you the naked Truth alone, without the Ceremony of a farther beating?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Nothing but the Truth, and the whole Truth: o help thee Cudgel—

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: That's a damn'd concluion of a Sentence: but ince it mut be o—Back and Sides, at your own peril—I et out from the Port in an unlucky Hour: the dusky Canopy of Night inveloping the Hemiphere.—

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Imprimis for Futian:—now proceed.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I tand corrected: in plain Proe then, I went darkling, and whitling, to keep my elf from being afraid; mumbling Cures betwixt my Teeth, for being ent at uch an unnatural time of Night.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How Sirrah, Curing and Swearing againt your Lord and Mater! take—

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Hold, Sir—pray conider, if this be not unreaonable, to trike me for telling the whole Truth, when you commanded me: I'll fall into my old dogtrot of lying again, if this mut come of plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: To avoid impertinences, make an end of your journey; and come to the Houe: what found you there a God's Name?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p:
I came thither in no God's Name at all; but in the Devils name, I found
before the Door a wingeing Fellow, with all my Shapes and Features; and accoutred alo in my Habit.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Who was that Fellow?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Who hou'd it be, but another Soia! a certain kind of other me: who knew all my unfortunate Commiion, preciely, to a word, as well as I Soia; as being ent by your elf from the Port, upon the ame errand to Alcmena.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What gros Aburdities are thee!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord, what Aburdities! as plain as any Packtaff. That other me, had poted himelf there before me, me. You won't give a Man leave to peak Poetically now; or ele I wou'd ay, That I was arriv'd at the Door, before I came thither.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: This mut either be a Dream, or Drunkennes, or Madnes in thee. Leave your Buffooning and Lying, I am not in humour to bear it, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I wou'd you hou'd know I corn a Lye, and am a Man of Honour in every thing, but jut Fighting. I tell you once again in plain incerity, and implicity of Heart, that before lat Night I never took my elf but for one ingle individual Soia; but, coming to our Door, I found my elf I know not how divided, and as it were plit into two Soia's.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Leave Buffooning: I ee you wou'd make me laugh, but you play the Fool curvily.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: That may be: but if I am a Fool, I am not the only Fool in this company.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How now Impudence! I hall—

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Be not in wrath Sir: I meant not you: I cannot poibly be the only Fool; for if I am one Fool, I mut certainly be two Fools; becaue, as I told you, I am double.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: That one hou'd be two, is very probable!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Have not you een a Six-pence plit into two halves, by ome ingenious School-Boy; which bore on either ide the Impreion of the Monarchs Face: now as thoe moieties were two Three-pences, and yet in effect but one Six-pence.—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: No more of your villanous Tropes and Figures.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Nay, if an Orator mut be diarm'd of his imilitudes.—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: A Man had need of patience, to endure this Gibberih: be brief, and come to a concluion.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: What wou'd you have Sir? I came thither, but the to'ther I was there before me: for that there was two I's, is as certain, as that I have two Eyes in this Head of mine. This I, that am here, was weary: the to'ther I was freh: this I was peaceable, and to'ther I was a hectoring Bully I.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: And thou expect't I hou'd believe thee?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: No, I am not o unreaonable: for I cou'd never have believ'd it my elf, if I had not been well beaten into it: But a Cudgel you know is a convincing Argument in a brawny Fit: What hall I ay, but that I was compell'd at lat to acknowledge my elf! I found that he was very I, without fraud, cozen, or deceit. Beides, I view'd my elf, as in a Mirror, from Head to Foot: He was Handome, of a noble preence, a charming Air, looe and free in all his Motions. And aw he was o much I, that I hou'd have reaon to be better atisfied with my own Peron, if his Hands had not been a little of the heaviet.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Once again to a Concluion: Say you pas'd by him, and entred into the Houe.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I am a Friend to Truth, and ay no uch thing: He defended the door and I could not enter.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: How, not enter!

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why, how hou'd I enter, unles I were a Spright to glide by him, and hoot my elf through Locks, and Bolts, and two-inch-boards?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: O Coward! Didt thou not attempt to pas?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Yes, and was repuls'd and beaten for my pains.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Who beat thee?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I beat Me.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Didt thou beat thy elf?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I don't mean I, here: but the abent Me, beat me here preent.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: There's no end of this intricate piece of Nonene.

sp.speaker: Soia
sp.p: 'Tis only Nonene becaue I peak it who am a poor fellow; but it wou'd be Sene, and ubtantial Sene, if a great Man aid it, that was back'd with a Title, and the Eloquence of ten Thouand Pounds a year.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: No more; But let us enter: Hold; my Alcmena is coming out, and has prevented me! How trangely will he be urpriz'd to ee me here, o unexpectedly!

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Make hate after me to the Temple; that we may thank the Gods for this glorious Succes, which Amphitryon has had againt the Rebels. Oh Heavens!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Thoe Heav'ns, and all their blet Inhabitants,
Grant, that the weet rewarder of my pains
May till be kind, as on our Nuptial Night.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: So oon return'd!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: So oon return'd! Is this my Welcome home?
So oon return'd, ays I am come unwih'd.
This is no Language of deiring Love:
Love reckons Hours for Months, and Days for Years:
And every little Abence is an Age.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: What ays my Lord?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: No, my Alcmena, no:
True Love, by its impatience meaures Time,
And the dear Object never comes too oon.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Nor ever came you o, nor ever hall
But you, your elf are chang'd from what you were,
Pall'd in Deires, and urfeited of Blis;
Not o I met you at your lat return;
When, Yeternight, I flew into your Arms,
And melted in your warm: Embrace.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Did not my Soul ev'n parkle at my Eyes,
And hoot it elf into your much lov'd Boome?
Did I not tremble with exces of Joy?
Nay agonize with pleaure at your ight,
With uch inimitable Proofs of Paion,
As no fale Love could feign!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: What's this you tell me?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Far hort of Truth, by Heav'n!
And you return'd thoe Proofs with Uury;
And left me, with a Sigh, at Break of Day.
Have you forgot?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Or have you dream't Alcmena?
Perhaps ome kind, revealing Deity,
Has whiper'd in your Sleep, the pleaing News
Of my Return; and you believ'd it real!
Perhaps too, in your Dream, you us'd me kindly;
And my preventing Image, reap'd the Joys
You meant awake to me.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Some Melancholy Vapour, ure, has eiz'd
Your Brain, Amphitryon, and diturb'd your Sene:
Or Yeternight is not o long a time,
But you might yet remember; and not force
An honet Bluh into my glowing Cheeks,
For that which lawful Marriage makes no Crime.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I thank you for my Melancholy Vapour.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: 'Tis but a jut requital for my Dream.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: I find my Mater took too much of the Creature lat night, and now is Angling for a Quarrel, that no more may be expected from him to Night, when he has no Aets.

div.stage: [In the mean time Amph. and Alch. walk by themelves, and frown at each other as they meet.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: You dare not jutifie it to my face.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Not what?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: That I return'd before this hour?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: You dare not, ure, deny you came lat night,
And taid till Break of Day?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: O Impudence!—Why Soia!

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Nay, I ay nothing; for all things here, may go by Enchantment (as they did with me) for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Speak, Phaedra; Was he here?

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: You know, Madam, I am but a Chamber-maid; and by my place, I am to forget all that was done over-night in Love-Matters,—unles my Mater pleae to rub up my Memory with another Diamond.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Now in the name of all the Gods, Alcmena,
A little recollect your catter'd Thoughts;
And weigh what you have aid.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I weigh'd it well, Amphitryon, e're I poke:
