And She, and Bromia, all the Slaves, and Servants,
Can witnes they beheld you, when you came.
If other Proof were wanting, tell me how
I came to know your Fight, your Victory,
The Death of Pterelas, in ingle Combat?
And, farther, from whoe hands I had a Jewel:
The Spoyls of him you lew.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: This is amazing!
Have I already given you thoe Diamonds,
The Preent I reerv'd?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: 'Tis an odd Quetion:
You ee I wear 'em; Look.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Now anwer, Soia.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Yes, now I can anwer with a fafe Concience, as to that point, all the ret may be Art Magick; but, as for the Diamonds, here they are, under afe cutody.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Then what are thee upon my Arm?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Flints, or Pebbles, or ome uch Trumpery of enchanted Stones.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: They ay the proof of a true Diamond is to glitter in the dark; I think my Mater had bet take my Lady into ome By-corner, and try whoe Diamond will parkle bet.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Yet now I think on't, Madam, did not a certain Friend of mine preent 'em to you?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: What Friend?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why another Soia; one that made himelf Soia in my depight, and alo unociated me.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Sirrah, leave your naueous Nonene: break open the Seal, and take out the Diamonds

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: More words than one to a Bargain, Sir; I thank you: That's no part of prudence for me to commit Burglary upon the Seals: Do you look firt upon the Signet, and tell me in your Concience, whether the Seals be not as firm as when you clapt the Wax upon them.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: The Signature is firm.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Then take the Signature into your own cutody, and open it; for I will have nothing done at my proper peril.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: O Heav'ns! Here's nothing, but an empty pace; the Net where they were laid.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Then if the Birds are flown, the Fault's not mine; here has been fine conjuring work; or ele the Jewel, knowing to whom it hou'd be given, took occaion to teal out, by a natural intinct, and ty'd it elf upon that pretty Arm.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Can this be poible!

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Yes, very poible: You, my Lord Amphitryon, may have brought forth another You my Lord Amphitryon, as well as I Soia have brought forth another Me Soia. and our Diamonds may have procreated thee Diamonds; and o we are all three double,

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: If this be true, I hope my Goblet has gigg'd another Golden Goblet: and then they may carry double upon all four.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: My Lord, I have tood ilent, out of wonder
What you cou'd wonder at.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: A chilling Sweat, a damp of Iealouie
Hangs on my Brows, and clams upon my Limbs.
I fear; and yet I mut be atisfied:
And, to be atisfy'd, I mut diemble.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Why mue you o, and murmur to your elf?
If you repent your Bounty, take it back

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Not o: but, if you pleae, relate what pat,
At our lat Enterview.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: That Quetion wou'd infer you were not here.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I ay not o;
I only wou'd refreh my memory;
And have my Reaons to deire the Story.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.l: So: This is as good port for me as an Examination of a great
Belly before a Magitrate.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: The Story is not long: you know I met you,
Kis'd you, and pret you cloe within my Arms,
With all the tendernes of Wively Love.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I cou'd have par'd that Kindnes.
And what did I?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: You train'd me with a Mafculine Embrace;
As you wou'd queeze my Soul out.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Did I o?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: You did.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Confound thoe Arms that were o kind—
Proceed, proceed.—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: You wou'd not tay to up; but, much complaining of your drowines, and want of natural Ret—

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Made hate to Bed: Ha, was't not o? Go on—
And tab me with each Syllable thou peak't.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.l: So, now 'tis coming, now 'tis coming.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I have no more to ay.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Why, went we not to Bed?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Why not?
Is it a Crime for Husband and for Wife
To go to Bed, My Lord?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Perfidious Woman!

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Ungrateul Man!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: She jutifies it too!

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I need not jutifie: Of what am I accus'd?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Of all that prodigality of Kindnes,
Giv'n to another, and uurp'd from me.
So bles me Heav'n, if ince my firt departure,
I ever et my foot upon this Threhold.
So am I innocent of all thoe Joys,
And dry of thoe Embraces.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Then I, it eems, am fale?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: As urely fale, as what thou ay't is true.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I have betray'd my Honour, and my Love?
And am a foul Adultres?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: What thou art,
Thou tand't condemn'd to be, by thy Relation.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Go, thou unworthy Man; for ever go:
No more my Husband; go thou bae Impotour;
Who tak't a vile pretence to taint my Fame;
And, not content to leave, wouldt ruine me.
Enjoy thy wih'd Divorce: I will not plead
My Innocence, of this pretended Crime:
I need not; pet thy Venom; do thy wort:
But know, the more thou wou'dt expoe my Vertue,
Like puret Linen laid in open Air,
'Twill bleach the more, and whiten to the view.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: 'Tis well thou art prepar'd for thy Divorce:
For, know thou too, that after this Affront,
This foul Indignity, done to my Honour,
Divorcement is but petty Reparation:
But, ince thou hat, with Impudence affirm'd
My fale Return, and brib'd my Slaves to vouch it,
The Truth hall, in the face of Thebes be clear'd;
Thy Unkle, the Companion of my Voyage,
And all the Crew of Sea-men, hall be brought,
Who were embark'd, and came with me to Land;
Nor parted, till I reach'd this cured Door:
So hall this Viion of my late Return,
Stand a detected • ye; and woe to thoe
Who thus betray'd my Honour.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.l: Sir, Shall I wait on you?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: No, I will go alone: Expect me here.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.l: Pleae you—that I—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Oh! Nothing now can pleae me:
Darknes, and Solitude, and Sighs, and Tears,
And all th'ineparable Train of Grief,
Attend my Steps for ever—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: What if I hou'd lye now, and ay we have been here before? I never aw any good that came of telling truth.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: He makes no more Advances to me: I begin a little to upect, that my Gold Goblet will prove but Copper.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis reolv'd, I will lye abominably, againt the Light of my own Concience. For uppoe the tother Soia has been here: perhaps that trong Dog has not only beaten me, but alo has been predominant upon my Wife, and mot carnally mius'd her! Now, by asking certain Quetions of her, with a Side-Wind, I may come to undertand how Squares go; and whether my Nuptial Bed be violated.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Mot certainly he has learn'd Impudence of his Mater; and will deny his being here: but that hall not erve his turn, to cheat me of my Preent!— [Aide. Why Soia! What, in a brown Study?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.l: A little cogitabund, or o; concerning this dimal Revolution in our Family!

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: But that hou'd not make you neglect your duty to me, your Mitres.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Pretty Soul; I wou'd thou wert: upon condition that old Bromia were ix Foot under ground.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: What! Is all your hot Courthip to me, dwindl'd into a poor unprofitable Wih? You may remember, I did not bid you abolutely depair.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: No; for all things yet may be accommodated, in an amicable manner, betwixt my Mater and my Lady.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: I mean, to the Buines, betwixt you and me—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why, I hope we two never quarrell'd?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Mut I remember you of a certain Promie that you made me at our lat parting?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Oh, when I went to the Army: that I hou'd till be praiing thy Beauty to Judge Gripus, and keep up his Affections to thee.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, I mean the Buines betwixt you and me this Morning—: that you promis'd me—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: That I promis'd thee.—I find it now: That trong Dog, my Brother Soia, has been here before me, and made Love to her.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You are conidering, whether or no, you hould keep your Promie—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: That I hou'd keep my Promie.—The truth on't is, he's anotherghes Morel than old Bromia.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And I had rather you hould break it, in a manner, and, as it were, and in ome Sene.—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: In a manner, and as it were, and in ome Sene, thou ay't?—I find, the trong Dog has only tickl'd up her Imagination, and not enjoy'd her: o that with my own Limbs, I may perform the weetnes of his Function with her. [Aide. No, weet Creature, the Promie hall not be broken; but what I have undertaken, I will perform like a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then, you remember the Preliminaries of the Preent—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Yes, yes, in gros I do remember, omething; but this diturbance of the Family, has omewhat tupify'd my Memory: Some pretty Quelque choe, I warrant thee; ome acceptable Toy, of mall value.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You may call a Gold Goblet, a Toy: But I put a greater value upon your Preents.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: A Gold Goblet, ay't thou! Yes, now I think on't, it was a kind of a Gold Goblet; as a Gratuity after Conummation.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, no; I had rather make ure of one Bribe before hand, than be promis'd ten Gratuities.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Yes, now I remember, it was, in ome Sene, a Gold Goblet, by way of Earnet; and it contain'd—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: One large—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: How, one large—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Gallon.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p:
No; that was omewhat too large, in Concience: It was not a whole Gallon; but it may contain, reaonably peaking, one large—Thimble-full:
But Gallons and Thimble-fulls are o like, that in peaking, I might eaily mitake them.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Is it come to this? Out Traytor!

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I had been a Traytor, indeed, to have betray'd thee to the wallowing of a Gallon: but a Thimblefull of Cordial-water, is eaily ipt off: and then, this ame Goblet, is o very light too, that it will be no Burthen, to carry it about with thee, in thy Pocket.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: O Apotate to thy Love! O perjur'd Villain! [Enter Bromia. What, are you here, Bromia! I was telling him his own: I was giving him a Rattle for his Treacheries to you, his Love: You ee I can be a Friend, upon occaion.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Ay, Chicken, I never doubted of thy Kindnes: but, for this Fugitive—this Rebel,—this Micreant.—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: A kind Welcome, to an abent Lover, as I have been.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Ay; and a kind Greeting you gave me, at your Return; when you us'd me o barbarouly, this Morning.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: The t'other Soia has been with her too: and has us'd her barbarouly: barbarouly, that is to ay, uncivilly: and uncivilly; I am afraid that means, too civilly.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You had bet deny you were here this Morning! And by the ame Token—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Nay, no more Tokens, for Heaven's ake, dear Phaedra.
Now mut I ponder with my elf a little, whether it be better for me, to have been here, or not to have been here, this Morning.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Phaedra, My Lord's without; and will not enter till he has firt poken with you.

sp.speaker: Phaed
sp.p: Oh that I could tay to help worry thee for this Abue: To him in private. but the bet on't is, I leave thee in good hands—Farewell Thimble.—To him, Bromia.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: No; you did not beat me, and put me into a Swound, and deprive me of the natural ue of my Tongue for a long Half-hour: You did not beat me down, with your little Wand: But I hall teach you to ue your Rod another time—I hall.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Put her into a Swound, with my little Wand, and o forth: That's more than ever I cou'd do. Thee are terrible Circumtances that ome Soia or another, has been here: Now, if he has literally beaten her, Grammercy, Brother Soia; he has but done, what I wou'd have done, if I had durt: But I am afraid it was only a damn'd Love-figure; and that the Wand that lay'd her aleep, might ignifie the Peace-maker.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Now you are nuffling upon a cold Scent, for ome pitiful Excue: I know you: twenty to one, but you will plead a Drunkennes: You are usd to be pot-valiant.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I was pumping, and I thank her, he has invented for me.—Yes Bromia, I mut confes I was exalted: and, poibly, I might coure upon thee, or perhaps be a little more familiar with thy peron, by the way of Kindnes, than if I had been ober; but, prithee, inform me what I did; that I may conider what atisfaction I am to make thee.

sp.speaker: Bromia.
sp.p: Are you there, at your Dog-tricks! You wou'd be forgetting, wou'd you? like a drunken Bully that affronts over-night, and, when he is call'd to account, the next Morning, remembers nothing of the Quarrel; and asks pardon, to avoid fighting.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: By Bacchus, I was overtaken; but I hou'd be loth that I committed any folly with thee.

sp.speaker: Bromia.
sp.p: I am ure, I kept my elf awake all night, that I did, in expectation of your coming.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: But what amends did I make thee, when I came!

sp.speaker: Bromia.
sp.p: You know well enough, to my orrow; but that you play the Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I warrant, I was montrous kind to thee.—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Yes, montrous kind indeed: You never aid a truer word: for, when I came to kis you, you pull'd away your Mouth, and turn'd your Cheek to me.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: How, Good! Here's fine Impudence: He jutifies!—.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Yes, I do jutifie, that I turn'd my Cheek, like a prudent peron, that my Breath might not offend thee: for, now I remember, I had eaten Garlick.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Ay, you remember, and forget, jut as it makes for you, or againt you: but, to mend the matter, you never poke one civil word to me: but tood like a tock, without ene or motion.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Yet better.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: After which, I lovingly invited you to take your place in your Nuptial Bed, as the Laws of Matrimony oblige you: and you inhumanly refus'd me.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Ay, there's the main point of the Buines! Art thou morally certain, that I refus'd thee: Look me now in the ace, and ay I did not commit Matrimony with thee!

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I wonder how thou cant look me in the face, after that refual!

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Say it once again, that I did not feloniouly come to Bed to thee!

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: No, thou cold Traytor, thou know't thou didt not.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Bet of all; 'twas dicreetly done of me to abtain.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: What do you inult upon me too!

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: No, I do not inult upon you;—but—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: But what? How was it dicreetly done then? Ha!

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Becaue it is the receiv'd Opinion of Phyicians, that nothing but puling Chitts, and Booby-Fools, are procreated in Drunkennes.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p:
A receiv'd Opinion, Snivel-guts! I'll be judg'd by all the marry'd Women of this Town, if any one of 'em has receiv'd it: The Devil take the Phyicians, for medling in our Matters: If a Husband will be rul'd by them, there are five weeks of Abtinence in Dog-days too; for fear a Child that was
got in Augut, hould be born jut nine Months after, and be blear-ey'd, like a May-Kitten.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Let the Phyicians alone; they are honet Men, whatever the World ays of 'em. But, for a certain reaon, that I bet know, I am glad that Matter ended o fairly and peaceably betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Yes 'twas very fair and peaceable: to trike a Woman down, and beat her mot outrageouly.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Is it poible that I drubb'd thee!

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I find your drift: You wou'd fain be provoking me to a new Trial now: but, i'faith, you hall bring me to no more handy-blows: I hall make bold to trut to my Tongue hereafter: You never durt have offer'd to hold up a finger againt me, till you went a Trooping.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Then I am a Conqueror: and I laud my own Courage: This Renown I have atchiev'd by Souldierhip and Stratagem. Know your Duty, Spoue, henceorward to your upream Commander.

div.stage: Enter Jupiter and Phaedra, attended by Muicians and Dancers.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Indeed I wondred at your quick return.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Ev'n o Almighty Love will have it, Phaedra;
And the tern Goddes of weet-bitter Cares,
Who bows our Necks beneath her brazen Yoke.
I wou'd have mann'd my heart, and held it out;
But, when I thought of what I had poet;
Thoe joys, that never end, but to begin,
O, I am all on fire to make my peace:
And die, Jove knows, as much as I can die,
Till I am reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I fear 'twill be in vain.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: 'Tis difficult:
But nothing is impoible to Love:
To Love like mine; for I have prov'd his force,
And my Alcmena too has felt his Dart.
If I ubmit, there's hope.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: 'Tis poible I may ollicit for you.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: But wilt thou promie me to do thy hot?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.l: Nay I promie nothing—unles you begin
To promie firt.—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: I wou'not be ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Well; I'll try to bring her to the Window: You hall have a fair hoot at her: if you can bring her down, you are a good Markes-man.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: That's all I ask:
And I will o reward thee, Gentle Phaedra.—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: What, with Cats-guts and Roin! This Sol-la; is but a lamentable, empty, ound.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Then there's a ound will pleae thee better.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.l: Ay, there's omething of Melody in this ound.
I cou'd dance all day, to the Muick of Chink Chink.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Go Soia round our Thebes,
To Polydas, to Tranio, and to Gripus,
Companions of our War; invite 'em all,
To joyn their Pray'rs to mooth Alomena's Brow;
And, with a olemn Feat, to crown the day.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Let me embrace you, Sir.—

Nay, you mut give me leave to expres my Gratitude; I have not eaten, to ay eating, nor drunk, to ay drinking, never ince our villanous encamping o near the Enemy: 'Tis true, I cap'd the bloody-Flux, becaue I bad o little in my Bowels to come out and I durt let nothing go, in Concience, becaue I had nothing to wallow in the room on't.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: You, Bromia, ee that all things be prepar'd,
With that Magniicence, as if ome God
Were Guet, or Mater here.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Or rather, as much, as if twenty Gods were to be Guets, or Maters here.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: That you may eat for to day, and to morrow.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Or, rather again, for to day and yeterday; and as many Months backwards, as I am indebted to my own Belly

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Away both of you.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Now I have pack'd him hence; thou, other Soia,
(Who, tho' thou art not preent, hear't my voice,)
Be ready to attend me at my Call;
And to upply his place.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: See, he appears:
This is my Bribe to Phaedra; when I made
This Gold, I made a greater God than Jove,
And gave my own Omnipotence away.

div.stage: Jupiter igns to the Muicians; Song and Dance: after which, Alcmena withdraws, frowning.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: CElia, that I once was blet

l.hi: Is now the Torment of my Bret;
Since to cure me, you bereave me
Of the Pleaures I poet:
Cruel Creature, to deceive me!
Firt to love, and then to leave me!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Had you the Blis refus'd to grant,
Then I had never known the want:
But poeing once the Bleing,
Is the Caue of my Complaint:
Once poeing is but tating;
'Tis no Blis that is not lating.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Celia now is mine no more;

l.hi: But I am hers; and mut adore:
Nor to leave her will endeavour;
Charms, that captiv'd me before,
No unkindnes can diever;
Love that's true, is Love for ever.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: O tay.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: She's gone; and eem'd to rown at parting.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Follow, and thou halt ee her oon appeas'd:
For I, who made her, know her inward tate;
No Woman, once well pleas'd, can throughly hate:
I gave 'em Beauty, to ubdue the trong:
(A mighty Empire, but it lats not long:)
I gave 'em Pride to make Mankind their Slave;
But, in exchange, to Men I Flattery gave:
Th' offending Lover, when he lowet lies,
Submits, to conquer; and but kneels, to rie.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: The FOURTH ACT.
div.stage: Jupiter following Alcmena; Mercury and Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.l: O Stay, my dear Alcmena, hear me peak.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: No, I wou'd fly thee, to the ridge of earth,
And leap the Precipice, to cape thy ight.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: For pity—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Leave me, thou ungrateful Man.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I cannot leave you: no; but like a Ghot
Whom your Unkindnes murder'd, will I haunt you.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Once more, be gone: I'm odious to my elf
For having lov'd thee once.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Hate not the bet and fairet of your kind:
Nor can you hate your Lover, tho' you wou'd:
Your Tears, that fall o gently, are but grief:
There may be Anger; but there mut be Love.
The Dove, that murmurs at her Mate's neglect,
But counterfeits a coynes, to be courted.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Courthip, from thee, and after uch affronts!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Is this that everlating Love you vow'd,
Lat Night, when I was circled in your arms?
Remember what you wore.—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Think what thou wert, and who cou'd wear too much?
Think what thou art, and that unwears it all.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Can you forake me, for o mall a fault?
'Twas but a Jet, perhaps too far puru'd:
'Twas but at mot, a Trial of your Faith,
How you cou'd bear unkindnes:
'Twas but to get a reconciling Kis,
A wanton Stratagem of Love.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: See how he doubles, like a hunted Hare,
A Jet, and then a Trial, and a Bait;
All tuff, and dawbing!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Think me jealous, then:

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: O that I cou'd; for that's a noble Crime;
And which a Lover can, with eae, forgive:
'Tis the high pule of Paion, in a Fever;
A ickly draught, but hews a burning Thirt:
Thine was a Surfeit, not a Jealouie:
And in that loathing of thy full gorg'd Love,
Thou aw't the naueous Object, with didain.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: O think not that: for you are ever new:
Your fruits of Love, are like eternal Spring
In happy Climes, where ome are in the bud,
Some green, and ripening ome, while others fall.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Ay, now you tell me this,
When rous'd deires, and freh recruits of force,
Enable languih'd Love to take the field.
But never hope to be receiv'd again:
You wou'd again deny you were receiv'd;
And brand my potles Fame.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I will not dare to jutifie my Crime,
But only point you where to lay the blame:
Impute it to the Husband, not the Lover.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: How vainly wou'd the Sophiter divide,
And make the Husband and the Lover, two!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Yes 'tis the Husband is the guilty Wretch:
His Inolence forgot the Sweets of Love,
And, deeming them his due, depis'd the Feat.
Not o the famih'd Lover cou'd forget:
He knew he had been there, and had been blet,
With all that Hope can wih, or Sene can bear:

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Husband, and Lover, both alike I hate.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: And I confes I have deerv'd that hate:
Too charming fair, I kneel for your forgivenes:
I beg by thoe fair eyes,
Which gave me wounds, That time can never cure;
Receive my Sorrows, and retore my Joys.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Unkind, and cruel! I can peak no more

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: O give it vent Alcmena, give it vent;
I merit your reproach, I wou'd be curs'd:
Let your Tongue cure me, while your Heart forgives.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Can I forget uch Uage!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Can you hate me?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I'll do my bet: for ure I ought to hate you.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: That Word was only hatch'd upon your Tongue,
It came not from your Heart. But try again,
And if, once more, you can but ay, I hate you,
My Sword hall do you jutice.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Then, I hate you.—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Then you pronounce the Sentence of my Death?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I hate you, much; but yet I love you more.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: To prove that Love, then ay, that you forgive me:
For there remains but this Alternative:
Reolve to pardon, or to punih me.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Alas, what I reolve appears too plain:
In aying that I cannot hate, I pardon.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: But what's a Pardon worth, without a Seal?
Permit me, in this Tranport of my Joy—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Forbear; I am offended with my elf,
sp.stage: Putting him gently away with her Hand.
sp.l: That I have hewn this Weaknes.—Let me go,
Where I may bluh, alone.—
But come not you:
Let I hou'd poil you, with exces of Fondnes,
And let you love again.—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Forbidding me to follow, he invites me:
This is the Mould of which I made the Sex:
I gave 'em but one Tongue, to ay us nay;
And two kind Eyes, to grant. Be ure that none
Approach, to interrupt our privacy

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Your Lady has made the Challenge of Reconciliation to my Lord: Here's a fair Example for us two, Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No Example at all, Soia: for my Lady had the Diamonds aforehand, and I have none of the Gold Goblet.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: The Goblet hall be forth-coming; if thou wilt give me weight for weight.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Yes, and meaure for meaure too, Soia: that is, For a Thimbleful of Gold, a Thimbleful of Love.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What think you now, Phaedra? Here's Pulling out the Goblet in a Cae, from under his Cloak. a weighty Argument of Love for you.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Now Jupiter, of his Mercy, let me kis thee, O thou Taking it in both Hands. dear Metal!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And Venus, of her Mercy, let me kis thee, dear, dear Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Not o fat, Soia! there's a damn'd Proverb in your way: Many things happen betwixt the Cup and the Lips, you know.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why, thou wilt not cheat me of my Goblet?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Yes; as ure as you wou'd cheat me of my Maiden-head: I am yet, but jut even with you, for the lat Trick you play'd me. And, beides; this is but a bare Retaining Fee; you mut give me another, before the Caue is open'd.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Shall I not come to your Bed ide, to Night?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, nor to Morrow-Night, neither: but this hall be my Sweet-heart in your place: 'tis a better Bed-fellow, and will keep me warmer, in cold Weather.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
Now, what's the God of Wit in a Woman's Hand? This very Goblet I tole from Gripus; and he got it out of Bribes too. But this is the common fate of ill gotten Goods, that as they came in by Covetounes, they go out by Whoring.—Oh, here's Amphitryon again, but I'll
[Enter Amphitryon. manage him above, in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Not one of thoe I look'd for, to be found!
As ome Enchantment hid 'em from my ight!
Perhaps, as Soia ays, 'tis Witchcraft all:
Seals may be open'd, Diamonds may be tol'n;
But how I came, in peron, yeterday,
And gave that Preent to Alcmena's hands,
That which I never gave, nor ever came,
O there's the Rock, on which my Reaon plits:
Wou'd that were all! I fear my Honour, too!
I'll try her once again: She may be mad:
A wretched Remedy; but all I have,
To keep me from depair.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: This is no very charitable Action of a God, to [From the Balcony, ue him ill, who has never offended me: but my Planet (Aide. net dipoes me to Malice: and when we great Perons do but a little Michief, the World has a good bargain of us.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: How now! what means the locking up of my Doors, at this time of day?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Softly, Friend, oftly: You knock as loud, and as awcily, as a Lord's Footman, that was ent before him, to warn the Family of his Honour's Viit. Sure you think the Doors have no feeling! What the Devil are you, that rap with uch Authority?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Look out, and ee: 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You: What You?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: No more, I ay, but open.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I'll know to whom firt?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I am one that can command the doors open.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Then you had bet command 'em, and try whether they will obey You.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Dot thou not know me!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Prithee, how hou'd I know thee? Dot thou take me for a Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: What's this Midummer-Moon? Is all the World gone a madding? Why Soia!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That's my Name indeed: Didt thou think I had forgot it!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Dot thou ee me?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why, dot thou pretend to go inviible? If thou hat any buines here, dipatch it quickly; I have no leaure to throw away upon uch pratling Companions.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Thy Companion, Slave? How dar't thou ue this inolent Language to thy Mater!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How! Thou my Mater? By what Title? I never had any other Mater, but Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Well: and for whom dot thou take me?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: For ome Rogue or other; but what Rogue I know not.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Dot thou not know me for Amphitryon, Slave!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How hou'd I know thee, when I ee thou dot not know thy elf! thou Amphitryon? In what Tavern hat thou been? And how many Bottles did thy buines, to metamorphoe thee into my Lord?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I will o drub thee, for this inolence.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How now, Impudence! are you threatning your Betters! I hou'd bring you to condign punihment, but that I have a great repect for the good Wine, though I find it in a Fool's Noddle.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: What, none to let me in? Why Phaedra! Bromia!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Peace Fellow; if my Wife hears thee, we are both undone. At a word, Phaedra and Bromia are very buie; one in making a Cawdle for my Lady; and the other in heating Napkins, to rub down my Lord, when he ries from Bed.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Amazement eizes me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: At what art thou amaz'd? My Mater and my Lady had a falling out, and are retir'd, without Seconds, to decide the Quarrel. If thou wert not a meddleome Fool, thou woud't not be thruting thy Noe into other Peoples Matters. Get thee about thy buines, if thou hat any; for I'll hear no more of thee.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Brav'd by my Slave, dihonour'd by my Wife,
To what a dep'rate plunge am I reduc'd,
If this be true the Villain ays? But why
That feeble, If! It mut be true; She owns it.
Now, whether to conceal, or blaze th' Affront?
One way, I pread my infamy abroad;
And, t'other, hide a burning coal, within;
That preys upon my Vitals: I can fix
On nothing, but on Vengeance.

div.stage: Enter to him Soia, Polydas, Gripus, Tranio.

sp.speaker: Gripus.
sp.p: Yonder he is; walking hatily to and fro, before his door; like a Citizen, clapping his Sides before his Shop, in a froty Morning: 'tis to catch a Stomach, I believe.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I begin to be affraid, that he has more tomach to my Sides, and Shoulders, than to his own Victuals. How he hakes his head! and tamps, and what trides he fetches! He's in one of his damn'd Moods again; I don't like the Looks of him.

sp.speaker: Amph
sp.p: Oh, my mannerly, fair-poken, obedient Slave, are you there! I can reach you now, without climbing: Now we hall try who's drunk, and who's ober.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why this is as it hou'd be: I was omewhat upicious that you were in a petilent humour; Yes, we will have a crah at the Bottle, when your Lordhip pleaes: I have ummo'nd 'em, you ee; and they are notable Topers; epecially Judge Gripus.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Yes, 'faith; I never refue my Glas, in a good Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Why, thou inolent Villain; I'll teach a Slave how to ue his Mater thus.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Here's a fine buines towards! I am ure I ran as fat as ever my legs cou'd carry me, to call 'em: nay you may trut my diligence, in all affairs belonging to the belly.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: He has been very faithfull to his Commiion, I'll bear him witnes.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: How can you be witnes, where you were not preent? the Balcony! Sirrah, the Balcony!

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why, to my bet remembrance, you never invited the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: What nonence dot thou plead for an Excue, of thy foul language, and thy bae replies!

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: You fright a man out of his enes, firt; and blame him, afterwards, for talking nonence:—but 'tis better for me to talk nonence, than for ome to do nonence: I will ay that, what e'er comes on't. Pray Sir, let all things be done decently: what, I hope, when a man is to be hang'd, he is not trus'd upon the Gallows, like a dumb Dog, without telling him wherefore.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: By your pardon, Gentlemen: I have no longer patience to forbear him.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Jutice, jutice, my Lord Gripus: as you are a true Magitrate, protect me. Here's a proces of Beating going forward, without entence given.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: My Lord Amphitryon, this mut not be: Let me firt undertand the demerits of the Criminal.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Hold you to that point, I beeech your Honour, as you commierate the Cae of a poor, innocent Malefactour.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: To hut the door againt me, in my very face, to deny me entrance, to brave me from the Balcony, to laugh at me, to threaten me: what proofs of Innocence call you thee? but if I punih not this Inolence— [Is going to beat him and is held by Polydas and Tranio. I beg you let me go—

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I charge you in the King's name, hold him fat; for you ee he's bloodily dipos'd.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now, what hat thou to ay for thy elf, Soia?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I ay, in the firt place, be ure you hold him, Gentlemen; for I hall never plead worth one farthing, while I am bodily affraid.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: Speak boldly; I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Then, if I may peak boldly, under my Lord's favour, I do not ay he lyes neither: no, I am too well bred for that: but his Lordhip fibbs mot abominably.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Do you hear his Impudence? yet will you let me go?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: No Impudence at all, my Lord: for how cou'd I, naturally peaking, be in the Balcony, and affronting you; when at the ame time I was in every Street of Thebes, inviting thee Gentlemen to Dinner?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Hold a little: how long ince was it that he poke to you, from the aid Balcony?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Jut now; not a Minute before he brought you hither.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Now peak my Witnees.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I can anwer for him, for this lat half hour.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Now judge equitably, Gentlemen; whether I was not a civil well-bred peron, to tell my Lord he fibbs onely.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Who gave you that order, to invite 'em?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: He that bet might; your elf: by the ame token, you bid old Bromia provide and 'twere for a God; and I put in for a brace, or a leae; no, now I think on't, it was for ten couple of Gods, to make ure of plenty.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: When did I give thee this pretended Commiion?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why you gave me this pretended Commiion, when you were jut ready to give my Lady the Fiddles and a Dance; in order, as I uppoe, to your econd bedding.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Where, in what place, did I give this order?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Here, in this place; in the preence of this very door, and of that Balcony: and if they cou'd peak, they wou'd both jutifie it.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: O Heaven! thee accidents are o urprizing, that the more I think of 'em, the more I am lot in my imagination.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Nay, he has told us ome paages, as he came along, that eem to urpas the power of Nature.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: What think you now, my Lord, of a certain twin Brother of mine, call'd Soia? 'tis a ly Youth: pray Heaven you have not jut uch another Relation, within doors, call'd Amphitryon. It may be it was he, that put upon me, in your likenes: and perhaps he may have put omething upon your Lordhip too, that may weigh heavy upon the forehead.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Let me go:—Soia may be innocent, and I will not hurt him:—Open the door; I'll reolve my doubts immediately.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: The door is peremptory, that it will not be open'd without Keys: and my Brother, on the inide, is in poeion; and will not part with 'em.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Then 'tis manifet that I am affronted; break open the door there.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Stir not a man of you, to his aitance.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Dot thou take part with my Adultres too, becaue he is thy Niece?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I take part with nothing, but the Law; and, to break the doors open, is to break the Law.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Do thou command 'em, then.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I command nothing without my Warrant; and my Clerk is not here to take his Fees for drawing it.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: The Devil take all Jutice-brokers:—I cure him too when I have been hunting him all over the Town, to be my Witnes!—But I'll bring Souldiers to force open the doors, by my own Commiion.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Pox o'thee forms of Law, to defeat a man of a Dinner, when he's harp et: 'tis againt the priviledge of a free-born Stomack; and is no les than ubverion of Fundamentals. [Jupiter above in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: Oh, my Friends, I am orry I have made you wait o long: you are welcome; and the door hall be open'd to you, immediately.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Was not that Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Why, who hou'd it be ele?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: In all appearance it was he: but how got he thither?

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: In uch a trice too!

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: And after he had jut left us?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: And o much alter'd, for the better, in his humour?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Here's uch a company of foolih quetions, when a man's a hungry: You had bet tay dinner till he has prov'd himelf to be Amphitryon in form of Law: But I'll make hort work of that buines: for I'll take mine Oath 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I hou'd be glad it were.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: How glad it were? with your damn'd Interrogatories, when you ought to be thankfull, that o it is.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: That I may ee my Mitres Phoedra, and preent her with my great gold Gobblet.

sp.speaker: Soia,
sp.p: If this be not the true Amphitryon, I wih I may be kept without doors, fating, and biting my own Fingers, for want of Victuals; and that's a dreadfull Imprecation! I am for the inviting, and eating, and treating Amphitryon: I am ure 'tis he that is my lawfully begotten Lord: and if you had an Ounce of true Jutice in you, you ought to have laid hold on t'other Amphitryon, and committed him for a Rogue, and an Impotour, and a Vagabond.

div.stage: [The Door is open'd: Mercury from within.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Enter quickly, Maters: The Paage on the right-hand leads to the Gallery, where my Lord expects you:—for I am call'd another way.

div.stage: [Gripus, Tranio, and Polydas go into the Houe.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I hou'd know that Voice, by a ecret Intinct: 'tis a Tongue of my Family; and belongs to my Brother Soia: it mut be o; for it carries a cudgelling kind of ound in it.—But put the wort: let me weigh this matter wiely: Here's a beating, and a belly-full: againt no beating, and no belly-full. The beating is bad; but the dinner is good: now, not to be beaten, is but negatively good; but, not to ill my belly, is poitively bad.—Upon the whole matter, my final reolution is, to take the good and the bad as they come together.
sp.stage: [Is entring: Mercury meets him at the Door.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Whither now, you kitchen-skumm? From whence this Impudence, to enter here without permiion?

sp.speaker: Soia,
sp.p: Mot Illutrious Sir: my Ticket is my hunger: hew the full Bowe's of your Compaion, to the empty bowels of my famine.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Were you not charg'd to return no more? I'll cut you into quarters, and hang you upon the Shambles.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: You'll get but little credit by me: Alas, Sir, I am but mere Carrion! Brave Soia, compaionate Coward Soia: and beat not thy elf, in beating me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Who gave you that privilege, Sirrah, to aume my Name? have you not been ufficiently warn'd of it? and receiv'd part of punihment already?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: May it pleae you, Sir, the Name is big enough for both of us: and we may ue it in common, like a Strumpet: witnes heaven, that I wou'd have obey'd you, and quitted my Title to the name; but, where ever I come, the malicious world will call me Soia, in pight of me: I am enible there are two Amphitryons; and why may not there be two Soia's? Let thoe two cut one anothers throats at their own pleaure: but you and I will be wier, by my conent, and hold good Intelligence together.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, no: Two Soia's wou'd but make two fools.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Then let me be the fool; and be you the prudent peron: and chue for your elf ome wier name: or you hall be the Elder Brother; and I'll be content to be the Younger; though I loe my Inheritance.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I tell thee, I am the onely Son of our Family.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Then let me be your Batard Brother, and the Son of a Whore; I hope that's but reaonable.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, Thou halt not digrace my Father: For there are few Batards now-a-days worth owning.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Ah! Poor Soia! What will become of thee?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Yet again profanely uing my proper name?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I did not mean my elf: I was thinking of another Soia, a poor fellow, that was once of my acquaintance, unfortunately banih'd out of doors, when dinner was jut coming upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Soia, you and I mut—Bles me! What have we here, a Couple of you, or do I ee double?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I wou'd fain bring it about, that I might make one of 'em: But he's unreaonable and will needs incorporate me, and wallow me whole into himelf. If he wou'd be content to be but one and a half, 'twou'd never grieve me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Tis a pervere Racal: I kick him, and cudgel him to no purpoe: for till he's obtinate to tick to me: and I can never beat him out of my reemblance.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Which of you two is Soia? For t'other mut be the Devil.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: You had bet ask him that has play'd the Devil with my back and ides.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You had bet ask him who gave you the gold Gobblet?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, that's already given: but he hall be my Soia, that will give me uch another.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I ind you have been Interloping, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: No, indeed, Sir; I onely promied her a gold Thimble: which was as much as comes to my proportion of being Soia.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: This is no Soia for my money: beat him away t'other Soia: he grows inufferable.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Wou'd I were valiant, that I might beat him away; and ucceed him at the dinner; for a pragmatical Son of a Whore, as he is—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What's that you are muttering betwixt your Teeth, of a Son of a Whore, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I am ure I meant you no offence: for, if I am not Soia, I am the Son of a Whore, for ought I know: and, if you are Soia, you may be the Son of a Whore for ought you know.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What ever I am, I will be Soia, as long as I pleae: and whenever you viit me, you hall be ure of the civility of the Cudgel.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: If you will promie to beat me into the houe, you may begin when you pleae with me: but, to be beaten out of the houe, at dinner time, fleh and bloud can never bear it.

div.stage: Mercury beats him about, and Soia is till making towards the door: but Mercury gets betwixt; and at length drives him off the Stage.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: In the name of wonder, what are you, that are Soia, and are not Soia?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: If thou would't know more of me, my peron is freely at thy dipoing.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then I dipoe of it to you again: for 'tis o ugly, 'tis not for my ue.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I can be ugly or handome, as I pleae: go to bed old, and rie young. I have o many Sutes of perons by me, that I can hift 'em when I will.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You are a fool then, to put on your wort Cloaths, when you come a wooing.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Go to: Ask no more quetions; I am for thy turn; for I know thy heart: and ee all thou hat about thee.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then you can ee my back-ide too; there's a bargain for you.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: In thy right pocket:—let me ee:—three Love Letters from Judge Gripus, written to the bottom, on three ides; full of futian paion, and hearty non-ence: as alo in the ame Pocket, a Letter of thine intended to him; coniting of nine lines and a half: crawl'd and fale pell'd, to how thou art a Woman; and full of fraudulence, and equivocations, and hoeing-horns of Love to him; to promie much, and mean nothing; to how, over and above, that thou art a mere Woman.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Is the Devil in you, to ee all this? Now, for Heavens ake, do not look into t'other Pocket.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Nay, there's nothing there, but a little godly Prayer-book, and—a bawdy Lampoon, and—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Look no farther, I beeech you.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And a Silver Spoon—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: —Ah!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Which you purloin'd lat Night from Bromia.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Keep my Counel, or I am undone for ever.
sp.stage: Holding up her hands to him.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No: I'll mortifie thee, now I have a handle to thy Iniquity, if thou wilt not love me.—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Well, if you'll promie me to be ecret, I will love you: becaue indeed I dare doe no other.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Tis a good Girl; I will be ecret; and further, I will be aiting to thee in thy filching: for thou and I were born under the ame Planet.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And we hall come to the ame end too, I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No; no; ince thou hat wit enough already to couzin a Judge, thou need't never fear hanging.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And will you make your elf a younger man; and be handome too: and rich? for you that know hearts, mut needs know, that I hall never be contant to uch an ugly old Soia.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Thou halt know more of that another time: in the mean while, here's a cat of my Office for thee.

div.stage: He tamps upon the ground: ome Dancers come from underground: and others from the ides of the Stage: A Song, and a fantatiok Dance.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: FAir Iris I love, and hourly I dye,

l.hi: But not for a Lip, nor a languihing Eye:
She's fickle and fale, and there we agree;
For I am as fale, and as fickle as he:
We neither believe what either can ay;
And, neither believing, we neither betray.

lg.head: II.

l.hi: 'Tis civil to wear, and ay things of coure;
We mean not the taking for better for wore.
When preent, we love; when abent, agree:

lg.l: I think not of Iris, nor Iris of me:

l.hi: The Legend of Love no Couple can find
So eaie to part, or o equally join'd.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: This Power of yours makes me upect you for little better than a God; but if you are one, for more certainty, tell me what I am jut now thinking.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why, thou art thinking, let me ee; for thou art a Woman, and your minds are o variable, that it's very hard even for a God to know them. But, to atisfie thee, thou art wihing, now, for the ame Power I have exercis'd; that thou mightet tamp, like me; and have more Singers come up for another Song.

sp.speaker: Phaedra,
sp.p: Gad, I think the Devil's in you. Then I do tamp in ome body's Name, but I know not whoe; (tamps.) Come up, Gentle-folks, from below; and ing me a Patoral Dialogue, where the Woman may have the better of the Man; as we always have in Love matters.

div.stage: [New Singers come up and ing a Song.

div.head: A Patoral Dialogue betwixt Thyris and Iris.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: FAir Iris and her Swain

l.hi: Were in a hady Bow'r;

lg.l: Where Thyris long in vain

l.hi: Had ought the Shepherd's hour:
At length his Hand advancing upon her nowy Breat;
He aid, O kis me longer,
And longer yet and longer,
If you will make me Blet.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: An eaie yielding Maid,
By truting is undone;
Our Sex is oft betray'd,
By granting Love too oon.
If you deire to gain me, your Suff'rings to redres;
Prepare to love me longer,
And longer yet, and longer,
Before you hall poes.

lg.head: III.

l.hi: The little Care you how,
Of all my Sorrows pat;
Makes Death appear too low,
And Life too long to lat.

lg.l: Fair Iris kis me kindly, in pity of my Fate;

l.hi: And kindly till, and kindly,
Before it be too late.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: You fondly Court your Blis,
And no Advances make;
'Tis not for Maids to kis,
But 'tis for Men to take.
So you may Kis me kindly, and I will not rebell;
And kindly till, and kindly,
But Kis me not and tell.

lg.head: V.
A RONDEAU.
lg.l: Thus at the height we love and live,
And fear not to be poor:
We give, and give, and give, and give,
Till we can give no more:
But what to day will take away,
To morrow will retore.
Thus at the heighth we love and live,
And fear not to be poor.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Adieu, I leave you to pay the Muick: Hope well Mr. Planett; there's a better Heav'n in tore for you: I ay no more, but you can gues.

sp.speaker: Mercury,
sp.l: Such Bargain-loves, as I with Phaedra treat,
Are all the Leagues and Friendhips of the Great:
All eek their Ends; and each wou'd other cheat
They onely eem to hate, and eem to love;
But Int'ret is the point on which they move.
Their Friends are Foes; and Foes are Friends agen;
And, in their turns, are Knaves, and Honet men.
Our Iron Age is grown an Age of Gold:
'Tis who bids mot; for all Men wou'd be old.

div.head: ACT. V.
div.stage: Gripus has the Gobblet in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: YOU will not be o bae to take it from me?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: 'Tis my proper Chattel: and I'll eize my own, in whatever hands I find it.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You know I onely how'd it you to provoke your generoity, that you might out-bid your Rival with a better Preent.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: My Rival is a Thief: and I'll indite you for a Receiver of Stoln Goods.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Thou Hide-bound Lover

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Thou very mercenary Mitres!

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Thou mot mercenary Magitrate!

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Thou Seller of thy elf!

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Thou Seller of other People: thou Weather-cock of Government: that when the Wind blows for the Subject, point't to Priviledge; and when it changes for the Soveraign, veers to Prerogative.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Will you compound, and take it as my Preent?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No: but I'll end thy Rival to force it from thee.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: When a Thief is Rival to his Judge, the Hangman will oon decide the difference.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Save your good Lordhip.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: From an Impertinent Coxcomb: I am out of humour, and am in hat: leave me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Tis my duty to attend on your Lordhip, and to eae you of that undecent Burden.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Gold was never any Burden, to one of my Profeion.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: By your Lordhip's permiion, Phaedra has ent me to take it from you.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What, by Violence?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No; but by your Honour's permiion, I am to retore it to her, and perwade your Lordhip, to renounce your Pretenions to her.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Tell her flatly, I will neither do one, nor t'other.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: O my good Lord, I dare pas my word for your free conent to both.—Will your Honour be pleas'd to take your choice of one of thee?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Why thee are Swords: what have I to do with them?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Onely to take your choice of one of them; which your Lordhip pleaes; and leave the other to your mot Obedient Servant.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What, one of thee ungodly Weapons? take notice, I'll lay you by the heels, Sirrah: this has the appearance of an unlawfull bloody challenge.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You Magitrates are pleas'd to call it o, my Lord; but with us Swordmen, 'tis an honourable Invitation to the cutting of one anothers Throats.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Be anwer'd; I have no Throat to cut. The Law hall decide our Controverie.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: By your permiion, my Lord; it mut be dipatch'd, this way.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I'll ee thee hang'd before I give thee any uch permiion, to dipatch me into another World.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: At the leat, my Lord, you have no occaion to complain of my want of repect to you: you will neither retore the Gobblet, nor renounce Phaedra: I offer you the Combat; you refue it: all this is done in the forms of honour: it follows, that I am to affront, cudgel you, or kick you, at my own arbitrement; and I uppoe, you are too honourable not to approve of my proceeding.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Here's a new ort of Proces, that was never heard of in any of our Courts.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: This, my good Lord, is Law in Short-hand, without your long Preambles, and tedious Repetitions, that ignifie nothing, but to queeze the Subject: therefore, with your Lordhip's favour, I begin.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What's this for?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: To give you an occaion of returning me a box o'th' Ear: that o, all things may proceed methodically.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I put in no anwer, but uffer a Non-uit.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, my Lord; for the Cots and Charges are to be paid: will you pleae to retore the Cup?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I have told thee, no.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Then from your Chin, I mut acend to your Lordhip's Ears.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh, oh. Oh, oh.—Wilt thou never-leave lugging me by the Ears?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Not till your Lordhip will be pleas'd to hear reaon.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Take the Cup; and the Devil give thee joy on't.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And your Lordhip will farther be graciouly pleas'd, to releae all claims, titles, and actions whatoever to Phaedra: You mut give me leave to add one mall memento, for that too.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I renounce her, I releae her.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Phaedra; My Lord has been pleas'd to be very gracious; without puhing matters to extremity.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I over-heard it all: But give me Livery and Seiin of the Gobblet, in the firt place.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: There's an Act of Oblivion hou'd be pas'd too.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Let him begin to remember quarrels, when he dares; now I have him under my Girdle, I'll cap Veres with him to the end of the Chapter.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: At the lat I have got poeion without your Lordhip's Warrant; Phaedra, tell Alcmena I am here.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I'll carry no uch lying Meage: you are not here, and you cannot be here: for, to my knowledge, you are above with my Lady, in the Chamber!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: All of a piece, and all Witchcraft! Anwer me preciely; do't thou not know me for Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Anwer me firt: did you give me a Diamond, and a Pure of Gold?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Thou know't I did not.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then, by the ame token, I know you are not the true Amphitryon: if you are he, I am ure I left you in bed with your own Wife: now you had bet tretch out a leg; and feel about for a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I'll undo this Enchantment with my Sword; and kill the Sorcerer: Come up, Gentlemen, and follow me.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I'll ave you the labour; and call him down to confront you; if you dare attend him.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Now the Spell is ended, and Jupiter can enchant no more; or ele Amphitryon had not enter'd o eaily. [Gripus is tealing off.] —Whither now, Gripus? I have buines for you: if you offer to tir, you know what follows.

div.stage: Enter Jupiter, follow'd by Tranio and Polydas.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Who dares to play the Mater in my Houe?
What noie is this, that calls me from above,
Invades my oft reces, and privacy,
And, like a Tyde, breaks in upon my Love?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: O Heav'ns, what's this I ee?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.l: What Prodigy!

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.l: How, two Amphitryons!

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: I have beheld th' appearance of two Suns;
But till the fale, was dimmer than the true;
Here, both hine out alike.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: This is a ight, that like the Gorgon's head,
Runs through my limbs, and tiffens me to Stone.
I need no more inquire into my fate:
For what I ee, reolves my doubts too plain.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.l: Two drops of water, cannot be more like.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.l: They are two very ame's.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Our Jupiter is a great Comedian; he counterfeits mot admirably: ure his Priets have coppy'd their Hypocriie from their Mater.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Now, I am gather'd back into my elf,
My Heart beats high, and puhes out the Blood
To give me jut revenge on this Impotour.
If you are brave, ait me—not one tirs:
What are all brib'd to take th' Enchanters part?
'Tis true, the work is mine; and thus.—
sp.stage: [Going to ruh upon Jupiter; and is held by Tranio and Polydas.]

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.l: It mut not be.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Give him his way: I dare the Madman's wort:
But till take notice, that it looks not like
The true Amphitryon, to fly out, at firt
To brutal force: it hows he doubts his Caue,
Who dares not trut his reaon to defend it.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Thou bae Uurper of my Name, and Bed;
No les than thy Hearts-blood can wah away
Th' affronts I have utain'd.

sp.speaker: Tranio.
sp.l: We mut not uffer
So trange a Duel as Amphitryon
To fight againt himelf.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.l: Nor think we wrong you, when we hold your hands:
We know our duty to our General:
We know the tyes of Friendhip to our Friend:
But who that Friend, or who that Gen'ral is,
Without more certain proofs betwixt you two,
Is hard to be ditinguih'd, by our reaon:
Impoible by ight.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I know it; and have atisfy'd my elf:
I am the true Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: See again.
He huns the certain proofs; and dares not tand
Impartial Judgment, and award of right.
But ince Alcmena's honour is concern'd,
Whom, more than Heav'n, and all the World, I love;
This I propoe, as equal to us both.
Tranio, and Polydas, be you Aitants,
The Guards be ready to ecure th' Impotour,
When once o prov'd, for publick punihment;
And Gripus, be thou Umpire of the Caue.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I am content: let him proceed to Examination.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: On whoe ide wou'd you pleae that I hou'd give the Sentence?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
Follow thy Concience for once; but not to make a Cutom of it neither; nor to leave an evil precedent of Uprightnes to future
Judges. (Aide) 'Tis a good thing to have a Magitrate under Correction: Your old fornicating Judge, dare never give Sentence againt him that knows his haunts.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: Your Lordhip knows I was Mater of Amphitryon's Ship; and deire to know of him, what pas'd in private betwixt us two, at his Landing, when he was jut ready to engage the Enemy?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Let the true Amphitryon anwer firt.—

sp.speaker: Jupit. & Amph.
sp.p: My Lord I told him.—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Peace both of you:—'Tis a plain Cae they are both true; for they both peak together: but for more certainty, let the fale Amphitryon peak firt.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Now they are both ilent.—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Then it's as plain on t'other ide, that they are both fale Amphitryons.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Which Amphitryon hall peak firt?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Let the Cholerick Amphitryon peak; and let the peaceable hold his peace.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: You may remember that I whiper'd you, not to part from the Stern, one ingle Moment.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: You did o.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No more words then; I proceed to Sentence.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: 'Twas I that whiper'd him; and he may remember I gave him this reaon for it; That if our Men were beaten, I might ecure my own retreat.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: You did o.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now again he's as true as t'other.

sp.speaker: Tranio.
sp.p: You know I was Pay-mater: What directions did you give me the night before the Battle?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: To which of the You's art thou peaking?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: It hou'd be a double U: but they have no uch letter in their Tongue.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I order'd you to take particular care of the great Bag.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Why this is demontration.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: The Bag that I recommended to you, was of Tygers skin; and mark'd Beta.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: In adnes I think they are both Jugglers: Here's nothing, and here's nothing: and then hiccius doccius, and they are both here again.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: You peaceable Amphitryon, what Money was there in that Bag?

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: The umm in gros, amounted jut to fifty Attick Talents.

sp.speaker: Tran
sp.p: To a farthing?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Paugh: obvious, obvious.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Two thouand pieces of Gold were ty'd up in a Handkerchief by themelves.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I remember it.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Then 'tis dubious again.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: But the ret was not all Silver; for there were jut four thouand Bras half-pence.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Being but Bras, the proof is inconiderable: if they had been Silver, it had gone on your ide.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Death and Hell, you will not perwade me, that I did not kill Pterelas?

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: Nor you me, that I did not enjoy Alcmena?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: That lat was poyon to me.—
Yet there's one proof thou cant not counterfeit:
In killing Pterelas, I had a Wound
Full in the brawny part of my right Arme:
Where till the Scar remains: now bluh, Impotour;
For this thou cant not how.
sp.stage: [Bares his Arme; and hows the Scar, which they all look on.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: This is the true Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: May your Lordhip pleae.—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, it does not pleae me: hold your tongue, I charge you; for the Cae is manifet.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: By your favour then, this hall peak for me.
sp.stage: Bares his Arme; and hows it.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: 'Tis jut in the ame Mucle.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: Of the ame length and breadth; and the Scar of the ame blewih colour.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Did not I charge you not to peak? 'twas plain enough before: and now you have puzzled it again.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Good Gods, how can this be!

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: For certain there was but one Pterelas; and he mut have been in the Plot againt himelf too: for he was kill'd firt by one of them; and then rie again out of repect to t'other Amphitryon, to be kill'd twice over.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: No more of this; it ounds impoible
That two hou'd be o like, no difference found.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You'll find it true.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Then where's Alcmena's honour and her fame?
Farewell my needles fear; it cannot be:
This is a Cae too nice for vulgar ight:
But let me come; my Heart will guide my Eyes
To point, and tremble to its proper choice.
There neither was, nor is, but one Amphitryon;
And I am onely his.—
sp.stage: [Goes to take him by the Hand.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Away, Adultres!

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: My gentle Love: my Treaure and my Joy;
Follow no more, that fale and foolih Fire,
That wou'd milead thy Fame to ure detruction!
Look on thy better Husband, and thy friend,
Who will not leave thee lyable to corn,
But vindicate thy honour from that Wretch
Who wou'd by bae aperions blot thy vertue.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.stage: going to him, who embraces her.
sp.l: I was indeed mitaken; thou art he!
Thy Words, thy Thoughts, thy Soul is all Amphitryon.
Th' Impotour has thy Features, not thy Mind;
The Face might have deceiv'd me in my choice;
Thy kindnes is a Guide that cannot err.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: What in my preence to prefer the Villain!
O execrable cheat! I break the truce;
And will no more attend your vain deciions;
To this—and to the Gods I'll trut my Caue.
sp.stage: [Is ruhing upon Jupiter, and is held again.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Poor Man; how I contemn thoe idle threats!
Were I dipos'd, thou might't as afely meet
The Thunder lanch'd from the red arme of Jove:)
(Nor Jove need bluh to be Alcmena's Champion.)
But in the face of Thebes, he hall be clear'd:
And what I am, and what thou art, be known.
Attend, and I will bring convincing proof.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Thou wou'dt elude my Jutice, and ecape;
But I will follow thee, through Earth, and Seas;
Nor Hell hall hide thee, from my jut revenge.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: I'll pare thy pains: it hall be quickly een,
Bewixt us two, who eeks, and who avoids.—
Come in my Friends: and thou who eem't Amphitryon;
That all who are in doubt, may know the true.

div.stage: Jupiter re-enters the Houe: with him Amphitryon, Alcmena, Polydas, Tranio, and Guards.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.stage: to Grip. and Brom. who are following.
sp.l: Thou Gripus, and you Bromia; tay with Phaedra:
Let their affairs alone, and mind we ours:
Amphitryon's Rival hall appear a God:
But know before-hand, I am Mercury;
Who want not Heav'n, while Phaedra is on Earth.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: But, and't pleae your Lordhip, is my fellow Phaedra to be exalted into the Heav'ns, and made a Star?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: When that comes to pas, if you look up a-nights, I hall remember old kindnes, and vouchafe to twinkle on you.

div.stage: Enter Soia, peeping about him: and eeing Mercury, is tarting back.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Here he is again; and there's no paing by him into the Houe, unles I were a Spright, to glide in through the Key-hole.—I am to be a Vagabond I find.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Soia, come back.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: No I thank you; you may whitle me long enough; a beaten Dog has always the wit to avoid his Mater.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I permit thee to be Soia again.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: 'Tis an unfortunate Name, and I abandon it: he that has an itch to be beaten, let him take it up for Soia;—What have I aid now! I mean for me; for I neither am nor will be Soia.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But thou may't be o in afety: for I have acknowledg'd my elf to be God Mercury.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: You may be a God, for ought I know; but the Devil take me if ever I Worhip you; for an unmercifull Deity, as you are

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You ought to take it for an honour to be drubb'd by the hand of a Divinity.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I am your mot humble Servant, good Mr. God; but by the aith of a Mortal, I cou'd well have par'd the honour that you did me. But how hall I be ure that you will never aume my hape again?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Becaue I am weary of wearing o villanous an outide.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Well, well; as villanous as it is, here's old Bromia will be contented with it.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Yes, now I am ure that I may chatie you afely: and that there's no God, lurking under your appearance.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Ay; but you had bet take heed how you attempt it: for as Mercury has turn'd himelf into me, o I may take the toy into my head, to turn my elf into Mercury, that I may winge you off, condignly.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: In the mean time, be all my Witnees, that I take Phaedra for my Wife of the left hand; that is, in the nature of a lawfull Concubine.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You hall pardon me for believing you, for all you are a God: for you have a terrible ill name below: and I am affraid you'll get a Footman, intead of a Priet, to Marry us.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But here's Gripus hall draw up Articles betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: But he's damnably u'sd to fale Conveyancing:—Well be it o: for my Counel hall over-look 'em before I Sign: Come on, Gripus; that I may have him under black and white
sp.stage: [Here Gripus gets ready Pen, Ink, and Paper.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: With all my heart; that I may have thee under black and white hereafter.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Begin, begin; Heads of Articles to be made, &c. betwixt Mercury, God of Thieves—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And Phaedra, Queen of Gypies.—Imprimis, I promie to buy and ettle upon her an Etate, containing Nine thouand Acres of Land, in any part of Boeotia, to her own liking.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Provided always, that no part of the aid Nine thouand Acres hall be upon, or adjoyning to Mount Parnaus: for I will not be fobb'd off with a Poetical Etate.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Memorandum, that he be always contant to me; and admit no other Lover.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Memorandum, unles it be a Lover that offers more: and that the Contancy hall not exceed the Settlement.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Item, that he hall keep no Male Servants in her houe: Item, no Rival Lap Dog for a Bedfellow: Item, that he hall never pray to any of the Gods.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: What, wou'd you have me an Atheit?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No Devotion to any He-Deity, good Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Here's no proviion made for Children yet.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Well remember'd, Bromia: I bargain that my Eldet Son hall be a Hero, and my Eldet Daughter a King's Mitres.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That is to ay, a Blockhead, and a Harlot, Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: That's true; but who dares call 'em o? Then for the Younger Children:—but now I think on't, we'll have no more, but Mas and Mis; for the ret wou'd be but chargeable, and a burden to the Nation.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Yes, yes; the Second hall be a Fale Prophet: he hall have Wit enough to et up a New Religion: and too much Wit to dye a Martyr for it.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: O what had I forgot? there's Pin-money, and Ali-money, and Seperate maintenance, and a thouand things more to be conider'd; that are all to be tack'd to this Act of Settlement.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I am a fool, I mut confes; but yet I can ee as far into a Mill-tone as the bet of you: I have oberv'd that you Women-Wits are commonly o quick upon the cent, that you often over-run it: Now I wou'd ask of Madam Phaedra, that in cae Mr. Heaven there, hou'd be pleas'd to break thee Articles, in what Court of Judicature he intends to ue him?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: The fool has hit upon't:—Gods, and great Men, are never to be ued; for they can always plead priviledge of Peerage: and therefore for once, Mounieur, I'll take your word; for as long as you love me you'll be ure to keep it: and in the mean time I hall be gaining experience how to manage ome rich Cully; for no Woman ever made her Fortune by a Wit.

div.stage: It Thunders; and the Company within doors: Amphitryon, Alcmena, Polydas, and Tranio, all come running out, and joyn with the ret, who were on the Theatre before.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Sure 'tis ome God: he vanih'd from our ight,
And told, us we hou'd ee him oon return

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I know not what to hope, nor what to fear.
A imple Errour, is a real Crime;
And unconenting Innocence is lot.

div.stage: A econd Peal of Thunder. After which, Jupiter appears in a Machine.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Look up, Amphitryon, and behold above,
Th' Impotour God, the Rival of thy Love:
In thy own hape, ee Jupiter appear,
And let that ight, ecure thy jealous fear
Digrace, and Infamy, are turn'd to boat:
No Fame, in Jove's Concurrence can be lot:
What he enjoys, he anctifies from Vice;
And by partaking, tamps into a price.
'Tis I, who ought to murmur at my Fate;
Forc'd by my Love, my Godhead to tranlate;
When on no other terms I cou'd poes,
But by thy form, thy features, and thy dres;
To thee were giv'n, the Bleings that I ought,
Which ele, not all the bribes of Heav'n had bought.
Then take into thy Armes thy envy'd Love;
And, in his own depight, triumph o'er Jove.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Amphitryon and Alcmena, both tand mute, and know not how to take it.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: Our Soveraign Lord Jupiter is a ly Companion; he knows how to gild a bitter Pill.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: From this aupicious Night, hall rie an Heir,
Great, like his Sire, and like his Mother, fair:
Wrongs to redres, and Tyrants to dieize;
Born for a World, that wants a Hercules.
Monters, and Monter-men he hall ingage,
And toil, and truggle, through an Impious Age
Peace to his Labours, hall at length ucceed,
And murm'ring Men, unwilling to be freed,
Shall be compell'd to Happines, by need.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We all Congratulate Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Keep your Congratulations to your elves, Gentlemen: 'Tis a nice point, let me tell you that; and the les that is aid of it, the better. Upon the whole matter, if Amphitryon takes the favour of Jupiter in patience, as from a God, he's a good Heathen.

sp.speaker: Soia.
sp.p: I mut take a little extraordinary pains to night, that my Spoue may come even with her Lady, and produce a Squire to attend on young Hercules, when he goes out to eek Adventures; that when his Mater kills a Man, he may tand ready to pick his Pockets; and piouly relieve his Aged Parents. Ah, Bromia, Bromia; if thou hadt been as handome and as young as Phaedra; I ay no more, but ome-body might have made his Fortunes as well as his Mater, and never the wore Man neither.
sp.l: For, let the wicked World ay what they pleae,
The fair Wife makes her Husband live at eae:
The Lover keeps him too; and but receives,
Like Jove, the remnants that Amphitryon leaves:
'Tis true, the Lady has enough in tore,
To atisfie thoe two, and eke, two more:
In fine, the Man, who weighs the matter fully,
Wou'd rather be the Cuckold, than the Cully.

lg.l: I'M thinking, (and it almot makes me mad,)
How weet a time, thoe Heathen Ladies had.
Idolatry, was ev'n their Gods own trade;
They Worhipt the ine Creatures they had made.
Cupid, was chief of all the Deities;
And Love was all the fahion, in the Skies.
When the weet Nymph, held up the Lilly hand,
Jove, was her humble Servant, at Command.
The Treaury of Heav'n was ne're o bare,
But till there was a Penion for the Fair.
In all his Reign, Adultry was no Sin;
For Jove, the good Example did begin.
Mark, too when he uurp'd the Husband's name,
How civilly he av'd the Ladies fame.
The ecret Joys of Love, he wiely hid;
But you, Sirs, boat of more, than e'er you did.
You teize your Cuckolds; to their face torment 'em;
But Jove gave his, new Honours to content 'em.
And, in the kind remembrance of the Fair,
On each exalted Son, betow'd a Star.
For thoe good deeds, as by the date appears,
His Godhip, flourih'd full Two thouand Years.
At lat, when He and all his Priets grew old,
The Ladies grew in their devotion cold;
And, that fale Worhip wou'd no longer hold.
Severity of Life did next begin;
(And always does, when we no more can Sin.)
That Doctrine, too, o hard, in Practice, lyes,
That, the next Age may ee another rie.
Then, Pagan Gods, may, once again, ucceed;
And Jove, or Mars, be ready, at our need,
To get young Godlings; and, o, mend our breed.

div.head: A CATALOGUE of Mr. DRYDEN'S WORKS, as they are bound in Three Volumes in quarto, in the order they were written.

list.head: In the Firt Volume.
list.item: Conquet of Granada, in two Parts.

list.head: In the Second Volume.
list.item: Vindication of the Duke of Guie.

list.head: In the Third Volume.
list.item: ANnus Mirabilis, or, The Year of Wonders.
A Poem on the Return of King Charles II.
A Panegyrick on the Coronation of King Charles II.
A Poem to the Lord Chancellor Hide.
Elegy on the Death of King Charles II.

div.p: THE SONGS IN AMPHITRYON, WITH THE MUSICK.
LONDON, Printed by J. Heptintall for Jacob Tonon at the Judge's-Head in Chancery-Lane. MDCXC.

div.head: Firt Song, in the third Act.

lg.l:
<>
CE—lia, that I once was Blet,
<> is now the torment of—my Breat;
<> Since to cure me you bereave me,
<> of the plea-ure—I po—es't;
<> Cru—el Creature to deceive me;—
<> firt—to Love and then to leave me;
<> cru—el Creature to—de-ceive me,—
<> firt—to Love and—then to leave me;

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Had you the Blis refus'd to grant,
I then had never known the want;
But poeing,
Once the Bleing,
Is the caue of my complaint:
Once poeing, is but tating,
'Tis no Blis that is not lating.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Celia now is mine no more,
But I am hers and mut adore;
Nor to leave her,
VVill endeavour;
Charms that captiv'd me before
No unkindnes can diever;
Love that's true, is Love for ever.

div.head: The econd Song, in the fourth Act.

lg.l: <> For I—ris I—igh,—and—houre—ly dye,
<> but—not for a—Lip,—nor a—languihing—Eye;

<> —he's
Fickle and fale, and there we a—gree,
<> O thee—are the Vir—tues that Captivate me;
<> we nei—ther be—leive what ei—ther can—ay,—
<> and nei—ther be—lei—ving, we—nei—ther be—tray, we—tray.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: 'Tis civill to Swear and ay things of coure,
VVe mean not the taking, for better for wore;
VVhen preent we Love, when abent agree,
I think not of Iris, nor Iris of me;
The Legend of Love, no couple can find,
So eay to part, and o eaily joyn'd.

div.head: Lat Song. A Dialogue betwixt Thyris and Iris.

lg.l: <> FAir I—ris and her Swain, were in a ha-dy Bow'r
<> where Thyris long—in— Vain had ought the happy—hour:
<> at length his hand advancing upon her Snowy Breat,
